choices.text: Stop the treatment and follow up
Gradually taper the drug and stop treatment

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl, who is taking antiepileptics, has had a seizure-free period of 6 months. She has no family history of epilepsy. Her EEG is now normal and she has a normal neurological exam and intelligence. What would your advice be?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Continue treatment for another 18 months


In this clinical scenario, the patient has been on antiepileptic drugs for 6 months and has remained seizure-free. Although her EEG, neurological examination, and intelligence are normal, and there is no family history of epilepsy, the minimum recommended duration for antiepileptic treatment in patients who are seizure-free is typically 2 years. Therefore, it is advisable to continue the antiepileptic medication for another 18 months to reduce the risk of seizure recurrence.

 

The criteria for considering antiepileptic drug withdrawal after a seizure-free period include:

 

  • Normal central nervous system (CNS) examination, including intelligence.
  • Normal EEG and MRI.
  • Presence of a single seizure type.
  • No family history of epilepsy.

 

If the patient meets these criteria and has been seizure-free for at least 2 years, gradual dose reduction over 2-3 months is preferred to avoid sudden recurrence of seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stop the treatment and follow up:  Abrupt cessation of antiepileptic medication can lead to seizure recurrence, which is why immediate discontinuation is not recommended.

 

Option B. Gradually taper the drug and stop treatment:  Although tapering is advisable when stopping antiepileptic medication, this patient has been seizure-free for only 6 months, making her ineligible for withdrawal of treatment at this time. Withdrawal can be considered after she completes a seizure-free period of at least 2 years.

 

Option D. Continue lifelong treatment with antiepileptics: Lifelong treatment is unnecessary here, as the patient meets the criteria for potential future drug withdrawal. However, in specific epilepsy types, such as Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy (JME), lifelong treatment is often recommended due to a high risk of recurrence.

 

Educational Objective:


In cases of seizure-free patients on antiepileptics, the minimum recommended duration of therapy is 2 years before considering drug withdrawal, provided the patient meets all criteria for stopping treatment.

questions.text: Based on the image, a 60-year-old male patient with diabetes presents with progressive skin lesions. What could be the likely diagnosis? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Basal cell carcinoma

 

The image above displays a central rodent ulcer, which indicates basal cell carcinoma. This malignant tumor exhibits characteristics of slow local invasion and mainly affects the pilosebaceous skin.

 

Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC):

 

  • The most significant predisposing factor for basal cell carcinoma is exposure to ultraviolet radiation. Other risk factors include ionizing radiation, coal tar, aromatic hydrocarbons, and arsenic exposure.
  • Basal cell carcinoma predominantly affects middle-aged or elderly men with a history of excessive sun exposure, often among individuals with white skin, aged between 40 to 80 years.

 

Morphologically, basal cell carcinoma can be of 2 types:

 

1. Localized types: These are more common and include:

 

  • Nodular and nodulocystic BCC: Representing the majority of cases, these appear as pearly, waxy nodules with rolled borders and sometimes central ulceration or depression, known as umbilication.

 

 

  • Pigmented BCC: These are similar to nodular BCC but contain melanin, giving them a darker appearance.
  • Nevoid BCC: This type is rarer and can resemble benign moles.

 

2. Generalized types: These are less common and can be more challenging to treat due to their growth patterns:

 

  • Superficial multifocal and spreading BCC: Often appearing as scaly, erythematous patches that can be mistaken for eczema or psoriasis.
  • Infiltrative BCC: These grow more aggressively and can invade deeper tissues.
  • Cicatrizing (or sclerosing) BCC: This type can cause scarring as it grows.

 

While nodular BCC is the most common form, it is important for medical practitioners to recognize the less common types due to their growth patterns and potential for tissue destruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)

 

  • It typically presents as a firm, red nodule or a flat sore with a scaly crust as seen in the image below.

 

 

  • While it's possible for diabetic patients to develop SCC, the description provided fits BCC more closely.

 

Option C. Melasma

 

  • It is characterized by brown to gray-brown patches as seen in the image below.

 

 

  • It is usually seen on the face.
  • It is more common in women, especially during pregnancy, and is not typically associated with progressive lesions.

 

Option D. Discoid lupus erythematosus

 

  • It often presents as a chronic rash with red, inflamed, and scaly patches that can cause scarring, usually on the face, ears, and scalp, as seen in the image below.

 

 

  • It is an autoimmune condition and not directly linked to diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In an elderly patient, progressive pearly or waxy skin lesions, especially if located on sun-exposed areas, are likely indicative of basal cell carcinoma.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Page no 4.15, 51.3, 88.10-12, 141.1-16

Robbins basic pathology 10th edition page no 1148

Bailey & Loves short practice of surgery 27th edition Page no 599, 604-6011

questions.text: Fibers from the marked structure end in which of the following areas of the thalamus?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anterior nucleus

 

The anterior nucleus of the thalamus is where the fibres from the mamillary body, which is the structure seen in the above figure, terminate.

 

The third ventricle's floor is made up of two tiny, hemispherical, pea-sized eminences called mammillary bodies, which are arranged side by side. The anterior thalamic nucleus receives fibres from the medial mammillary nucleus.

 

The anterior thalamic nuclei have 3 subdivisions -anteroventral nucleus, anteromedial nucleus, and anterodorsal nucleus.

 

  • Major input: Mammillothalamic tract from the mammillary nuclei of the hypothalamus.
  • Major cortical output: Anterior limbic area, cingulate, and the parahippocampal gyrus
  • Major function:
    • Regulation of alertness and attention
    • Acquisition of memory

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior nucleus: The posterior nuclear group, also known as the pulvinar, is the largest nuclear group in the thalamus. It is involved in the integration of visual, auditory, and somatosensory information. The mammillothalamic tract does not terminate in the posterior nucleus.

 

Option B. Reticular nucleus: The reticular nucleus of the thalamus surrounds the lateral aspect of the thalamus and serves as a modulator of information transfer between different parts of the thalamus and the cerebral cortex. It primarily functions to regulate the activity of relay nuclei in the thalamus. While it plays an important role in modulating thalamic function, the mammillothalamic tract does not primarily terminate here.

 

Option D. Ventral Lateral nucleus: The ventral lateral nucleus is one of the principal relay nuclei of the thalamus that receives inputs from the cerebellum and the basal ganglia and projects to the primary motor cortex. It is involved in the coordination and planning of movements. The mammillothalamic tract does not terminate in the ventral lateral nucleus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior nuclear group of the thalamus is involved in emotional tone and recent memory. Fibers from the mammillary bodies, via the mammillothalamic tract, terminate in the anterior nuclei of the thalamus. The connection between the mammillary bodies and the anterior thalamic nucleus is a crucial part of the Papez circuit.

questions.text: Structures passing between marked points A and B? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stylopharyngeus

 

The stylopharyngeus muscle passes between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors. This muscle originates from the styloid process and inserts into the pharyngeal wall. It is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) and functions to elevate the pharynx during swallowing and speaking.

 

 

 

The gaps in the pharyngeal wall and structures passing thorugh them

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Palatopharyngeus: This muscle runs from the soft palate to the pharynx, but it does not pass between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors. Instead, it is involved in forming the palatopharyngeal arch.

 

Option C. Stylohyoid: This muscle originates from the styloid process and inserts onto the hyoid bone. It is involved in elevating the hyoid bone during swallowing but does not pass between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors.

 

Option D. Mylohyoid: This muscle forms the floor of the mouth and is involved in elevating the floor of the mouth during swallowing. It does not pass between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The stylopharyngeus muscle passes between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors, and it is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX).

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is the correct explanation of the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is not the correct explanation of the Assertion
Assertion is independently a true/correct statement but the Reason is independently an incorrect/false statement
Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement

questions.text:
Assertion: Distal pole of scaphoid is the most common carpal bone to undergo avascular necrosis.

 

Reason: Blood supply is retrograde from its distal to proximal end.
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement

 

SCAPHOID FRACTURE

 

  • Scaphoid is the most commonly fractured bone in the carpus, in adult as well as children. 
  • Scaphoid fracture is seen most commonly in males between the ages of 15 and 30. 
  • Middle third (waist) fractures are most common accounting for 70% of scaphoid fractures > proximal pole fracture (20%) > distal pole fracture (10%), in adults and adolescents.
  • Distal pole avulsion type fracture is most common fracture type in children.
  • Salient Features:
    • Most of the blood supply to the scaphoid enters distally, so blood supply of scaphoid diminishes proximally. 
    • This accounts for the fact that 1% of distal third, 20% of middle third, 40% of proximal third and 100% of proximal pole fractures result in avascular necrosis or non-union of the proximal fragment.
  • Complication: Non-union > Avascular necrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The proximal pole of scaphoid is the most common bone to undergo avascular necrosis. 
  • This is because the blood supply to the scaphoid is retrograde, from its distal end to its proximal end. 
  • At the proximal end, the blood supply diminishes. 
  • This accounts for increased chances of avascular necrosis or non-union of the proximal fragment when the proximal pole of the scaphoid is fractured.

questions.text: Which technique is used to identify auto antibodies? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Indirect immunofluorescence

 

  • Indirect immunofluorescence is a technique commonly used for the detection of autoantibodies. It involves applying the patient's serum to a substrate that expresses the antigen(s) of interest. If autoantibodies are present, they bind to these antigens. Then another anti-human antibody is added to amplify the response generated. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct Immunofluorescence: Used for tissue-bound antibodies where the patient's tissues are stained directly to detect deposits of immunoglobulins or complement.

 

Option B. ELISA: Mainly used for quantifying serum levels of specific antibodies against predefined antigens.

 

Option D. FISH (Fluorescent In Situ Hybridization): Used for identifying chromosomal abnormalities and gene mutations rather than detecting antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indirect immunofluorescence allows for the detection of circulating autoantibodies in patient serum by using antigen-expressing substrates, making it a critical tool for diagnosing various autoimmune diseases.

choices.text: Insulinoma; cystic duct, 2nd & 3rd part of the duodenum
Gastrinoma; CBD, 2nd & 3rd part of the duodenum
Gastrinoma; cystic duct, 2nd & 3rd part of the duodenum
Insulinoma; CBD, 2nd & 3rd part of the duodenum

questions.text: A patient with a history of peptic ulcer shows increased gastrin levels upon pentagastrin stimulation. What is the probable diagnosis and its anatomical boundaries? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gastrinoma; cystic duct, 2nd & 3rd part of the duodenum


The clinical presentation and elevated gastrin levels indicate Gastrinoma (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome). The anatomical area where gastrinomas are commonly found is called the Triangle of Passaro, which is bounded by:

 

  • Cystic duct superiorly
  • Second and third parts of duodenum medially
  • Head and neck of pancreas forming the third boundary.
  • Most common location within this triangle is the duodenum. 
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by:
    • Elevated fasting serum gastrin
    • Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy (SRS) shows 100% positivity

 

 

Other Options:


Option A. Insulinoma; cystic duct, 2nd & 3rd part of the duodenum: Incorrect. Insulinoma presents with Whipple's triad and hypoglycemia, not elevated gastrin levels.

 

Option B. Gastrinoma; CBD, 2nd & 3rd part of the duodenum: Incorrect. While gastrinoma is correct, the CBD is not the correct anatomical boundary - it's the cystic duct.

 

Option D. Insulinoma; CBD, 2nd & 3rd part of the duodenum: Incorrect. Neither the diagnosis (insulinoma) nor the anatomical boundary (CBD) is correct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastrinoma occurs within the Triangle of Passaro, bounded by the cystic duct, 2nd and 3rd parts of duodenum, and head/neck of pancreas, with duodenum being the most common location.

 

Gastrinoma

 

  • Malignant
  • Present in triangle of passaro
  • MC site: duodenum (D1)

 

 

Clinical feature: due to hypergastrinemia â€“ Zollinger ellison syndrome

 

  1. Recurrent peptic ulcer
  2. Ulcer at abnormal location
  3. Acid induced diarrhea

questions.text: A 51-year-old bomb blast victim is brought to the casualty with life-threatening injuries. There was a lot of chaos and no one was available to sign consent for emergency surgery. Despite surgery the patient died. The doctor is not responsible under which doctrine? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Doctrine of anticipation 

 

Core Concept

 

Operating without consent in life threatening emergency

 

  • IPC Section 92 - Act done in good faith for benefit of a person without consent
  • This means that the doctor can perform life-saving procedures in a patient with life-threatening injuries without obtaining consent specially if delay in treatment in order to obtain consent would result in harm to the patient. 
  • This is also called as the doctrine of anticipation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Res ipsa loquitur:

 

  • It is a Latin phrase for "the thing speaks for itself."
  • Here the Negligence is so obvious that it does not require expert testimony or specific evidence to establish a breach of the standard of care.
  • The event is unusual and wouldn't occur without negligence

 

Option C. Doctrine of extended consent: suppose some another pathology is discovered during surgery then another consent is taken. This is called doctrine of extended consent

 

Option D. Doctrine of conjugated consent: Consent for multiple procedures given together

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "Doctrine of anticipation," which permits medical interventions without prior consent in emergencies where delays could result in harm or death to the patient. This doctrine is crucial in understanding the legal protections afforded to doctors making critical decisions under duress and with the intent to save lives.

questions.text: What is the postmortem sign in which a gas shadow is present in the great vessels of a fetus in the case of intrauterine demise? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Robert‘s sign

 

Robert sign refers to the presence of a gas shadow within the heart or the greater vessels, in cases of fetal death in utero. It is a rare sign caused by postmortem blood degeneration, usually seen 1-2 days after death; and may be seen as early as 12 hours.

 

 

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Spalding sign – overlapping of the fetal skull bones caused by collapse of the fetal brain.

 

Option C. Ball sign - hyperflexion of the spine with crowding of ribs seen in intrauterine death.

 

Option D. Halo sign - increase in soft tissue width between subcutaneous fat and the cranial vault.

 

Educational objective

 

Roberts sign is characterized by the presence of gas shadows in the heart or great vessels of a fetus, indicating intrauterine demise and typically appearing 1-2 days postmortem.

choices.text: Kinetic perimetry is used in quantification and tracking of visual changes in established glaucoma
In Static perimetry, stimulus intensity is held constant and moved centrally with detection
Visual field defect to be classified as glaucoma, it should have the corresponding optic nerve head abnormalities
Early signs include generalised constriction of isopters and barring of blind spot

questions.text: Which of these statements is true regarding perimetry? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Early signs include generalised constriction of isopters and barring of blind spot


Initial indications of glaucoma in perimetry involve a widespread narrowing of isopters and the appearance of a blockage within the blind spot.

 

Perimetry is a diagnostic test used to assess a person's visual field.

 

Static Perimetry: Traditional method involving fixed stimulus points presented on a static grid. Goldmann perimetry and Humphrey Visual Field Analyzer are common devices for static perimetry.

 

Kinetic Perimetry: Moving stimuli are used to determine the boundaries of the visual field. Useful for mapping the extent of peripheral vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Kinetic perimetry involves moving a stimulus across the visual field to map the boundaries of each isopter. It is not specifically used for quantification and tracking of visual changes in established glaucoma; static perimetry is more commonly used for this purpose

 

Option B: In static perimetry, various light spots of different intensities are presented in different locations but do not move across the visual field. The statement in B inaccurately describes kinetic perimetry

 

Option C: While optic nerve head abnormalities are a critical diagnostic feature of glaucoma, visual field defects can exist without clear corresponding optic nerve changes, especially in early or mild cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perimetry is vital for early detection and monitoring of glaucoma. Generalized constriction of isopters and enlargement of the blind spot are key early signs that can indicate the presence of this eye condition.

questions.text: Indicated structure gives origin to which of the following fiber (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dentato-rubral

 

The indicated structure in the provided image is the dentate nucleus. The dentate nucleus is one of the deep cerebellar nuclei and is the largest and most lateral of these nuclei. It is involved in the planning, initiation, and control of voluntary movements.

 

The dentate nucleus gives rise to the dentato-rubral fibers. These fibers project from the dentate nucleus to the red nucleus in the midbrain, playing a crucial role in the coordination of motor movements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cerebello-rubral: Incorrect because while it involves the cerebellum and red nucleus, the correct specific term for the fiber originating from the dentate nucleus is "dentato-rubral."

 

Option B. Cerebello-reticul: Incorrect because this option refers to fibers connecting the cerebellum to the reticular formation, not specifically involving the dentate nucleus.

 

Option C. Cerebello-vestibul: Incorrect because this refers to fibers connecting the cerebellum to the vestibular nuclei, which are involved in balance and spatial orientation, not related to the dentate nucleus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dentate nucleus gives rise to the dentato-rubral fibers, which project to the red nucleus and are crucial for motor coordination.

choices.text: AIDP with migraine
Right side paralysis
Acute intermittent porphyria
Conversion disorder

questions.text: A 22-year-old female patient came with complaints of vomiting and a decrease in movement of the right leg. In the past, she has had episodes of violent and aggressive behavior and abdominal pain. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute intermittent porphyria

 

Vomiting & decreased movements of right leg in young female with previous history of abdominal pain and mental symptoms like violent and aggressive behavior points towards acute intermittent porphyria.

 

Acute intermittent porphyria is an autosomal dominant disorder.

 

It is due to deficiency of HMB Synthase enzyme.

 

ACUTE INTERMITTENT PORPHYRIA

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Common precipitating factors include endogenous and exogeneous steroids, porphyrinogenic drugs, alcohol ingestion and low-calorie diets, usually instituted for weight loss.
  • Symptoms are more common in women, suggesting a role for estrogens or progestins.
  • Abdominal pain, the most common symptom is usually steady and poorly localized but maybe cramping.
  • Nausea, vomiting, constipation, tachycardia hypertension, mental symptoms, pain in the limbs, head, neck or chest, muscle weakness, sensory loss, dysuria, and urinary retention are characteristic.
  • The peripheral neuropathy is due to neurologic axonal degeneration (rather than demyelination) and primarily affects motor neurons.
  • Mental symptoms such as anxiety, insomnia, depression, disorientation, hallucination and paranoia can occur in acute attacks.
  • Seizures can be due to neurologic effects or to hyponatremia (due to hypothalamic involvement and inappropriate vasopressin secretion or from electrolyte depletion due to vomiting, diarrhea, poor intake or excess renal sodium loss).

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • ALA & PBG levels are substantially increased in plasma and urine, especially during acute attacks.

 

Treatment:

 

  • I.V. Hemin is more effective and should be used as first line therapy for all acute attacks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AIDP with migraine: Incorrect because AIDP (Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy) presents with rapid onset muscle weakness and decreased reflexes, not specifically associated with vomiting or abdominal pain.

 

Option B. Right side paralysis: Incorrect as this diagnosis does not account for the broader spectrum of symptoms including behavioral changes and abdominal pain.

 

Option D. Conversion disorder: Incorrect because conversion disorder involves symptoms that suggest neurological or medical conditions but are actually manifestations of psychological conflict or needs. The specific clinical presentation and past medical history in this case strongly point towards a physiological rather than psychological cause.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The acute intermittent porphyria presents with a complex array of symptoms, including neurological, gastrointestinal, and psychiatric manifestations, and is associated with specific triggers and a genetic basis. Elevated ALA and PBG levels during attacks are diagnostic.

choices.text: Beta oxidation of branched chain fatty acid
Alpha oxidation of branched chain fatty acid
Omega oxidation of branched chain fatty acid

questions.text: Refsumâ€™s disease is caused by the defect of? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alpha oxidation of branched-chain fatty acid

 

Refsum's disease is a peroxisomal disorder caused by the impaired alpha-oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids, which results in the buildup of phytanic acid in the body. This accumulation of phytanic acid is a characteristic feature of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beta oxidation of branched-chain fatty acid: Refsum's disease is not caused by the defect in beta oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids. Beta oxidation is a different metabolic process.

 

Option C. Omega oxidation of branched-chain fatty acid: Refsum's disease is not caused by the defect in omega oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids. Omega oxidation is a different metabolic pathway.

 

Option D. Alpha oxidation of dicarboxylic acids: Refsum's disease primarily involves the defect in the alpha oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids, not the alpha oxidation of dicarboxylic acids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Characteristic of Peroxisomal pathways:

 

  • No ATP production in any of peroxisomal pathways
  • H2O2 is regularly formed which is neutralized by peroxisomal enzymes catalase & peroxidase.
  • Two pathways which occur in peroxisomes are:

1. Î±-Oxidation of branched chain fatty acids (BCFA)

2. Oxidation of Very Long Chain Fatty Acid (VLCFA)

 

Refsum's disease: Occur due to defect in Î±-oxidation of BCFA in peroxisomes due to defect in phytanic acid hydroxylase. So, Phytanic acid not oxidised.

  • Beta-oxidation occurs for saturated and even chain fatty acids like palmitic and stearic acid
  • In Omega-oxidation dicarboxylic acids are formed. In MCAD deficiency there is dicarboxylic acidosis and non-ketotic hypoglycemia.

questions.text: In which of the following scenarios is a liver transplant possible in the case of secondary tumours? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ca testis

 

  • Liver transplantation for metastatic cancer is generally considered with extreme caution due to the high risk of recurrence and the limited availability of organs. However, certain exceptions exist based on the specific type of cancer and its overall prognosis and responsiveness to other treatments. Here's an analysis of the scenarios mentioned:

 

In rare cases, liver transplantation might be considered for metastatic testicular cancer if it is isolated to the liver and the primary cancer is under control. Testicular cancer tends to have a better overall prognosis compared to many other cancers due to its high responsiveness to chemotherapy. If the metastasis is limited and other treatments have been effective, liver transplantation could be a potential option.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Melanoma: Liver transplantation is not typically recommended for metastatic melanoma due to the aggressive nature of the disease and the likelihood of widespread metastasis. Melanoma is known to respond poorly to immunosuppression, which is a requisite part of post-transplant care.

 

Option B. Breast Cancer (Ca breast): Like melanoma, metastatic breast cancer is generally not considered suitable for liver transplantation. Breast cancer can metastasize to multiple organs, and the post-transplant immunosuppression regime can exacerbate the spread and recurrence of the cancer.

 

Option D. Active Renal Cell Carcinoma (Active RCC): RCC is typically resistant to both chemotherapy and radiation, and like melanoma and breast cancer, is generally not considered suitable for liver transplantation due to poor outcomes associated with the disease's aggressive nature and potential for widespread metastatic sites.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Liver transplantation for metastatic cancer is rare and generally only considered under specific conditions. These conditions typically include the isolation of metastasis to the liver, good control of the primary cancer, and a lack of other effective treatment options. Each type of cancer must be evaluated on its own characteristics, including its responsiveness to treatment and overall prognosis.

questions.text: What is anisometropia? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Difference in refractive error

 

Anisometropia refers to a condition where there is a significant difference in the refractive error (i.e., the focusing power) between the two eyes. This difference can cause each eye to focus differently, leading to difficulties in binocular vision and sometimes resulting in amblyopia (lazy eye) if one eye is significantly more affected than the other.

 

  1. ANISOMETROPIA: Difference between Refractive Error of two eyes
  2. ANISEIKONIA: Difference between Image size in two eyes
  3. ANISOCORIA: Difference between Pupil size of two eyes
  4. ANISOPIA: Difference between vision of two eyes

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Difference in color of iris: Incorrect. This condition is called heterochromia, not anisometropia. Heterochromia refers to a difference in coloration, typically of the iris.

 

Option C. Difference in axial length: Incorrect. While differences in axial length can contribute to anisometropia, the term itself specifically refers to differences in refractive error, not just axial length.

 

Option D. Difference in visual acuity: Incorrect. Although anisometropia can lead to differences in visual acuity between the two eyes, the term specifically refers to the difference in refractive error, not visual acuity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anisometropia is defined as a difference in the refractive error between the two eyes, which can lead to difficulties in binocular vision and potentially cause amblyopia in the more affected eye.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with weight loss, mediastinal lymphadenopathy, and pleural effusion. Her HRCT shows a "tree-in-bud" pattern, indicating lung consolidation and effusion. Analysis of pleural fluid reveals high adenosine deaminase (ADA) levels with a predominance of lymphocytes. What is the most likely finding on lymph node biopsy? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Necrotizing epithelioid granuloma

 

This is a classic presentation of tuberculosis (TB):

 

  • "Tree-in-bud" appearance on HRCT indicates endobronchial spread â€” a hallmark of active pulmonary TB.
  • Mediastinal lymphadenopathy and pleural effusion with lymphocyte predominance further support a tuberculous etiology.
  • High ADA (>40 U/L) in pleural fluid is a strong indicator of TB pleuritis.

 

The most characteristic lymph node biopsy finding in TB is:

 

  • Necrotizing (caseating) epithelioid granulomas
  •  Composed of epithelioid cells (from activated macrophages), Langhans giant cells, and central caseous necrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fungal hyphae surrounded by lymphocytes:  Seen in invasive fungal infections (e.g., aspergillosis, histoplasmosis), more common in immunocompromised individuals; not typically associated with high ADA.

 

Option B. Anthracosis pigment: Black carbon pigment in lungs/lymph nodes from pollution or smoking. Not pathological in itself and doesnâ€™t cause systemic symptoms or effusion.

 

Option D. Reactive hyperplasia: Seen in viral or nonspecific bacterial infections. No granulomas or caseation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a young woman with systemic symptoms, tree-in-bud pattern, lymphocytic pleural effusion, and high ADA, TB is the most likely diagnosis. The hallmark histopathological finding is a necrotizing epithelioid granuloma.

choices.text: Supine with wedge under right hip
Trendelenburg with legs stirrup

questions.text: A woman presents with prolonged labor in emergency. She is being taken for a Cesarean section. Which of the following is the correct position in which the nurse should keep the patient on the OT table? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supine with wedge under right hip

 

Explanation:

 

The preferred position for a cesarean section is supine with a wedge under the right hip. This positioning is crucial to prevent supine hypotension syndrome, which is commonly seen in the third trimester of pregnancy.

 

Supine hypotension syndrome:

 

  • Occurs due to the pressure of the gravid uterus on the inferior vena cava (IVC) when the patient is in the supine position.
  • This pressure can cause hypotension, tachycardia, and syncope.
  • It is particularly dangerous during cesarean sections where spinal anesthesia can exacerbate hypotension.
  • A right tilt (placing a wedge under the right hip) helps to alleviate the pressure on the IVC, thereby preventing hypotension.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Semi fowlers: The individual lies on the bed with the head elevated 30-45 degrees. This position is not suitable for a cesarean section.

 

Option C. Trendelenburg with legs stirrup: This position involves having the head low and is not appropriate for a cesarean section. The reverse Trendelenburg position (head high) is also not suitable for this purpose.

 

Option D. Prone position: The prone position (lying face down) is inappropriate for cesarean sections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During a cesarean section, the patient should be positioned supine with a wedge under the right hip to prevent supine hypotension syndrome, which is caused by the pressure of the gravid uterus on the inferior vena cava.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 1405

questions.text:
Which of the following is false regarding disulfiram?

 

1. Stops alcohol craving

 

2. Accumulates acetaldehyde

 

3. Inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase

 

4. Starting dose is 500 mg
questions.solution:
Ans. B.  1 and 3

 

  • Alcohol is metabolized in the body with the help of alcohol dehydrogenase to aldehyde and further to acid with the help of aldehyde dehydrogenase.
  • Disulfiram inhibits Acetaldehyde dehydrogenase, which leads to accumulation of aldehyde in the body. This causes unpleasant symptoms like headache, vomiting, blurring of vision, etc. after consumption of alcohol due to the accumulated acetaldehyde.
  • So, disulfiram is used in alcohol aversion therapy, however it does not stop craving.
  • It should not be administered until the person has abstained from alcohol for at least 12 hours.
  • The disulfiram-alcohol reaction may persist as long as 14 days after the last dose of disulfiram.
  • Starting dose of disulfiram is 250 mg is also wrong as starting dose is 500mg/day for 1 week followed by 250 mg /day.

 

Other Options:

 

2.  Accumulates acetaldehyde: True. Disulfiram works by inhibiting aldehyde dehydrogenase, an enzyme involved in metabolizing alcohol. This inhibition leads to the accumulation of acetaldehyde when alcohol is consumed, causing the unpleasant effects.

 

4.  Starting dose is 500 mg: True. Starting dose of disulfiram is 250 mg is also wrong as starting dose is 500 mg/day for 1 week followed by 250 mg/day.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Disulfiram does not reduce alcohol cravings; it works by causing adverse reactions when alcohol is consumed, thereby discouraging drinking. It inhibits aldehyde dehydrogenase, not alcohol dehydrogenase, leading to the accumulation of acetaldehyde and subsequent unpleasant symptoms. The starting dose for disulfiram therapy is typically 250 mg per day.

questions.text: All of the following conditions are associated with Neurosecretory bodies except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adrenal cortical tumor

 

Neurosecretory bodies are not seen in adrenal cortical tumors.

 

Adrenocortical neoplasms produce aldosterone. Primary hyperaldosteronism due to a solitary aldosterone-secreting adenoma is Conn syndrome.

 

Microscopically, aldosterone-producing adenomas show spironolactone bodies which are eosinophilic, laminated cytoplasmic inclusions found after treatment with spironolactone.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medullary thyroid carcinoma: Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is a type of thyroid cancer that originates from parafollicular C-cells, which are neuroendocrine cells. These cells secrete calcitonin and often contain neurosecretory granules.

 

Option B. Pituitary adenoma: Pituitary adenomas are tumors of the pituitary gland, many of which are neuroendocrine in nature. They can produce hormones such as prolactin, growth hormone, or ACTH, and neurosecretory granules can be found in these tumors.

 

Option C. Paraganglioma: Paragangliomas are tumors that arise from paraganglia, which are collections of neuroendocrine cells. These cells are closely related to the sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems and often contain neurosecretory granules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neurosecretory bodies are associated with neuroendocrine tumors, but not with adrenal cortical tumors, which originate from the adrenal cortex and are involved in steroid hormone production.

 

Tumors associated with neurosecretory granules

choices.text: Joint pains with nodules on skin

questions.text: A 32-year-old female with history of back ache and polyarthralgia was investigated and found to have nucleolar pattern in IF. Which of the following is the best fit in her case? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Raynaud phenomenon and sclerodactyly

 

Nucleolar pattern refers to the presence of a few discrete spots of fluorescence within the nucleus and represents antibodies to RNA. This pattern is reported most often in patients with systemic sclerosis. Hence, Raynaud phenomenon and sclerodactyly will be seen.

 

 

Systemic sclerosis is more common in middle-aged women. The clinical manifestations include:

 

  • Claw-like flexion deformity of hands
  • Raynaudâ€™s phenomenon - manifested as episodic vasoconstriction of the arteries and arterioles of the extremities, is seen in virtually all patients and precedes other symptoms in 70% of cases
  • Esophageal fibrosis causing dysphagia and hypomotility
  • Malabsorption syndrome
  • Respiratory distress due to pulmonary fibrosis
  • Malignant hypertension
  • Pulmonary hypertension
  • Biliary cirrhosis.

 

Other IF Patterns: -

 

Examples of ICAP-classified IIFA staining patterns:

 

 

 

ENA: Extractable nuclear antigens; RNP; ribonucleoproteins; SLE; systemic lupus erythematous; MCTD: mixed connective tissue disease; PM: polymyositis; dsDNA: double-stranded deoxyribonucleic acid; CENP: centromere protein

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Genital and oral painful ulcers: These are more characteristic of BehÃ§et's disease, which is associated with HLA-B51 and presents with recurrent oral and genital ulcers, uveitis, and other systemic symptoms, not a nucleolar pattern on IF.

 

Option C. Glomerulonephritis and heart failure: These features are more consistent with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which may show a different pattern on IF, such as a homogenous or peripheral (rim) pattern, rather than the nucleolar pattern associated with systemic sclerosis.

 

Option D. Joint pains with nodules on skin: This description is typical of rheumatoid arthritis, which is associated with rheumatoid nodules and not the nucleolar pattern seen in systemic sclerosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The nucleolar pattern in IF is most often associated with systemic sclerosis, a condition characterized by Raynaud phenomenon and sclerodactyly, among other systemic manifestations.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page No. 405, 425

questions.text: Which protein is present in the HPV vaccine? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) L1

 

9-valent HPV vaccine (Gardasil-9) is a non-infectious recombinant vaccine prepared from the purified virus-like particles (VLPs) of the major capsid (L1) protein of HPV types 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58.

 

Available HPV vaccines protect against either two, four, or nine types of HPV. All HPV vaccines protect against at least HPV types 16 and 18, which cause the greatest risk of cervical cancer. It is estimated that HPV vaccines may prevent 70% of cervical cancer, 80% of anal cancer, 60% of vaginal cancer, 40% of vulvar cancer, and show more than 90% efficacy in preventing HPV-positive oropharyngeal cancers. They additionally prevent some genital warts, with the quadrivalent and nonavalent vaccines that protect against HPV types HPV-6 and HPV-11 providing greater protection.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. E6, E7: These proteins are oncogenes that contribute to the development of cancer by interfering with tumor suppressor proteins such as p53 and Rb but are not components of the vaccine.

 

Option C. E1, E2: These are early proteins involved in the replication and regulation of HPV DNA but are not used in the vaccine formulation.

 

Option D. L2: This is a minor capsid protein of HPV, but the vaccine primarily uses the major capsid protein L1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The HPV vaccine contains the L1 protein, which forms virus-like particles that induce an immune response to prevent infection by various HPV types, significantly reducing the risk of HPV-associated cancers and genital warts.

choices.text: Includes breathing, movements, tone, and Amniotic fluid volume
Can tell us about fetal outcome and fetal pH
Score is inconsistent with fetal pH at different gestational ages
Score <4: fetal pH <7.2; Score 0: 100% fetal acidemia

questions.text: All are true about biophysical profile (BPP) except? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Score is inconsistent with fetal pH at different gestational ages

 

Explanation:

 

  • BPP score is not inconsistent with fetal pH, but has a direct linear relationship with fetal pH and thus can be used to predict fetal acidemia.
  • BPP is a multi-parametric, screening test to assess uteroplacental insufficiency.
  • It consists of five components/ variables and the observations are made in a 30 minutes time period.
  • The Biophysical Profile has 5 components and is scored using Manning score
    • NST
    • Amniotic Fluid Volume
    • Fetal movement
    • Fetal Tone
    • Fetal Breathing

   

 

  • A low Manning score correlates with fetal hypoxia
  • Narcotics and sedatives can significantly lower the score
  • A BPP score of 0 was almost invariably associated with significant fetal acidemia, whereas a normal score of 8 or 10 was associated with normal pH.
  • An equivocal test resultâ€”a score of 6â€”was a poor predictor of an abnormal outcome. A drop in the BPP score from 2 or 4 down to 0 more accurately predicted an abnormal fetal outcome.
  • Overall, BPP scores provided poor sensitivity to predict cord blood pH
  • The Modified BPP has 2 components
    • NST
    • AFI

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Includes breathing, movements, tone, and Amniotic fluid volume: This statement is true. The BPP includes assessments of fetal breathing, movements, tone, and the Amniotic fluid volume as part of its evaluation.

 

Option B. Can tell us about fetal outcome and fetal pH: This statement is true. The BPP score helps predict fetal outcome and provides an indication of fetal pH, reflecting the level of fetal distress.

 

Option D. Score <4: fetal pH <7.2; Score 0: 100% fetal acidemia: This statement is true. A BPP score of less than 4 correlates with a fetal pH <7.2, and a score of 0 is almost invariably associated with significant fetal acidemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Biophysical Profile (BPP) provides a consistent prediction of fetal pH and outcome, with a lower score correlating with increased risk of fetal acidemia.

 

Ref: Page no 999, Williams Obstetric 26th edition

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true? (INICET Nov 2020)

 

  1. Morphine is used for treatment of pulmonary oedema
  2. Pethidine is used for treatment of pain due to biliary colic
  3. Indomethacin can cause headache
  4. Aspirin is used for treatment of peptic ulcer disease
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A and C

 

Aspirin can actually exacerbate peptic ulcer disease due to its mechanism of inhibiting prostaglandin production, which is protective for the gastric mucosa. It is more commonly associated with causing or worsening gastric ulcers rather than treating them.

 

A. Morphine is used for treatment of pulmonary edema: Morphine can be used in the acute management of pulmonary edema, particularly when it's due to heart failure. It reduces preload and afterload on the heart and can alleviate the associated anxiety and discomfort. However, its use has become less common due to concerns about potential side effects, including respiratory depression.

 

C. Indomethacin can cause headache: This is true. While Indomethacin is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used to treat pain, inflammation, and fever, one of its side effects can be headache.

 

Other options:

 

B. Pethidine is used for treatment of pain due to biliary colic: Pethidine (Meperidine) is generally not recommended for biliary colic because it can cause spasm of the sphincter of Oddi, potentially worsening pain in biliary coli due to its anticholinergic property.

 

D. Aspirin is used for treatment of peptic ulcer disease: This is false. Aspirin can actually exacerbate peptic ulcer disease due to its mechanism of inhibiting prostaglandin production, which protects the gastric mucosa. Aspirin is more commonly associated with causing or worsening gastric ulcers rather than treating them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Morphine can be used for the treatment of pulmonary edema, and indomethacin can cause headaches.
  • Aspirin is not used for the treatment of peptic ulcer disease and can actually worsen it. While opioids can be used for biliary colic, their use is not without complications, and not all opioids are appropriate for this condition.

questions.text: The most specific and typical sign of juvenile dermatomyositis in a 17-year-old patient is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gottron's papules

 

  • Gottron's papules are a characteristic and specific sign seen in juvenile dermatomyositis.
  • The classical diagnostic criteria for Juvenile Dermatomyositis include the presence of Gottron's papules and heliotrope rash.
  • Gottron's papules are identified as violaceous, lichenoid, inflammatory, flat-topped papules found on the extensor surfaces, particularly the knuckles ( proximal interphalangeal joints, distal interphalangeal joints, and metacarpophalangeal joints) as shown in the image below.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Photosensitive skin rash:

 

  • While photosensitivity can be a feature in some patients with juvenile dermatomyositis, it is not the most specific sign.
  • Photosensitive rashes are also common in other conditions like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) making it less specific to juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

Option B. Nail bed capillary changes:

 

  • Nail bed capillary changes, such as dilated or drop-out capillaries, can be seen in juvenile dermatomyositis as shown in the image below

 

 

  • However, these changes are also found in other connective tissue diseases, so they are not the most specific for juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

Option D. Malar rash:

 

  • A malar rash, or "butterfly rash" as shown in the image below is typically associated with SLE, not juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

 

  • Although skin manifestations can overlap between different connective tissue diseases, a malar rash is not specific to juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gottron's papules are flat-topped, red or violaceous papules. They are considered pathognomonic (specifically indicative) of dermatomyositis and are one of the hallmark features of the disease and represent the most specific sign of juvenile dermatomyositis in a 17-year-old patient.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 53, page nos. 53.4, 53.11

Nelson textbook of pediatrics 21st edition Page no 1182, 1183

questions.text: Which of the following is wrong regarding primary and secondary immune response? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4

 

The given statement that antibody affinity is higher in the primary immune response and lower in the secondary immune response is incorrect. The correct comparison should be:

 

  • Primary Immune Response: This occurs as a result of the first contact with an antigen. It typically involves a longer lag period (4-10 days) before antibodies are produced. The initial antibodies produced are primarily IgM, with lower affinity for the antigen.
  • Secondary Immune Response: This occurs as a result of subsequent exposures to the same antigen. It involves a shorter lag period (1-3 days) due to the presence of memory cells. The antibodies produced are primarily IgG, which have higher affinity for the antigen compared to those produced in the primary response. The secondary response is more rapid and robust, producing higher levels of antibodies that persist for a longer period.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Lag period: Correctly identified; the primary immune response has a longer lag period (4-10 days), while the secondary immune response has a shorter lag period (1-3 days).

 

Option B. Antibody response: Correctly identified; the secondary immune response is more potent than the primary immune response.

 

Option C. Isotype generated: Correctly identified; the primary response mainly produces IgM, while the secondary response mainly produces IgG.

 

Educational objective

choices.text: Give oral fluids and zinc supplementation only and ask mother to come back if danger sign develops.
Give oral fluids and ask mother to continue the same and visit again the next day.
Consider severe dehydration start IV fluids, IV antibiotics, and refer to higher centre.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought to the hospital with a history of loose stools. No history of fever or blood in stools. The mother says he is irritable and eagerly drinks water if given. On examination, eyes are sunken and in the skin pinch test, the skin retracted within two seconds but not immediately. What treatment is advised for the child? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Give oral fluids and zinc supplementation only and ask mother to come back if danger sign develops

 

In this question, the child has some dehydration because he or she is restless and irritable, drinks water freely, has sluggish skin retraction (2 seconds) on skin pinch test, and has sunken eyes.

 

Treatment according to the WHO Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Diseases (IMNCI) guideline plan B.

 

  • Oral rehydration therapy
  • Zinc supplements,
  • Sustained breastfeeding

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Give oral fluids and ask mother to continue the same and visit again the next day: Zinc supplementation is an important treatment protocol for diarrhea. In this option that point was missing, therefore this is not the right option.

 

Option C. Consider severe dehydration start IV fluids, IV antibiotics, and refer to higher centre: If the child was having refusal to drink with skin pinch more than 2 seconds, we could have thought of severe dehydration. Therefore this is not the right option.

 

Option D. Wait and observe: Child is eagerly drinking which is a feature of some dehydration, therefore, wait and observe is not the right option.

 

Educational Objective:


In a child with some dehydration, the recommended treatment includes oral rehydration therapy, zinc supplementation, and continued breastfeeding, with instructions to return if danger signs develop.

questions.text: A patient reports pain in the right upper abdomen. An ultrasound-guided FNAC of liver cysts reveals the presence of a parasitic organism. Which of the following is most likely to be the causative organism? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Echinococcus granulosus

 

Echinococcus granulosus is the causative organism for hydatid cyst of the liver. The diagnosis is based on:

 

  • Location - Liver is the most common site for hydatid cysts
  • Imaging - Characteristic appearance on ultrasound
  • FNAC findings - Demonstrates scolices and hooklets of Echinococcus
  • Life cycle involves: 
    • Definitive host: Dog
    • Intermediate host: Sheep
    • Accidental host: Humans (dead end)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Taenia saginata : Incorrect. Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm) does not typically cause liver cysts. It mainly affects the intestine.

 

Option C. Taenia solium: Incorrect. Taenia solium (pork tapeworm) is associated with neurocysticercosis affecting the brain and muscles, not liver cysts.

 

Option D. H. nana: Incorrect. Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm) is an intestinal parasite and does not cause liver cysts.

 

Educational Objective: 


Echinococcus granulosus is the causative organism for hydatid cysts of the liver, which is the most common site of hydatid disease.

questions.text: A person working in a restaurant comes to the casualty with a huge burn on his abdomen. On examination, the injury looks like below. What is the most likely cause of the injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Moist heat

 

  • In the case scenario given above the patient has suffered from a â€˜Scald injuryâ€™

  • Clinical presentation - erythema, blisters, and a line of demarcation

  • Cause of scald - application of liquid above 60Â°C or from steam which is moist heat.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electric burn: Electric burns typically have entry and exit points and are caused by electrical currents passing through the body, which is not seen in the image.

 

Option B. Chemical burn: Chemical burns result from exposure to corrosive substances and may have different patterns and additional signs such as discoloration or tissue damage beyond just blisters and erythema.

 

Option C. Dry heat: Burns caused by dry heat, such as flames or hot objects, usually present with charring or a different burn pattern compared to scald injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most likely cause of the burn injury shown in the image is moist heat, specifically a scald injury caused by hot liquids or steam.

 

TYPES of SCALD INJURIES

 

  • Immersion burns: Due to immersion in hot liquid, usually water.

  • Accidental Splash burns

  • Steam burns: Exposure to superheated steam.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most frequent presentation of an abdominal desmoid tumor? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Abdominal mass

 

The most common presentation of abdominal desmoid tumor is as an abdominal mass.

 

Abdominal mass is the most common presentation of abdominal desmoid tumors. These tumors are characterized by the development of firm, palpable masses in the abdominal wall or other abdominal structures. This is the hallmark sign of these tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abdominal pain: While abdominal pain can be a symptom of abdominal desmoid tumors, it is not the most frequent presentation. These tumors often manifest as painless masses in the abdominal area.

 

Option C. Fever: Fever is generally not a primary symptom of abdominal desmoid tumors. These tumors are primarily associated with the formation of masses rather than systemic symptoms like fever.

 

Option D. Rectal prolapse: Rectal prolapse is not a common presentation of abdominal desmoid tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An abdominal desmoid tumor is a tumor that arises from fibro-aponeurotic tissue in the musculoaponeurotic structures of the abdominal wall, especially below the level of the umbilicus.

 

Desmoid tumors are frequently seen to be associated with Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP) syndrome.

 

It commonly presents as a slow-growing mass and tends to infiltrate muscle in the immediate area. Eventually, it can undergo a myxomatous change and then shows an increase in size more rapidly.

 

The investigation of choice for desmoid tumor is MRI. Biopsy with immunohistochemistry can help in establishing the diagnosis. The tumors typically stain positive for

 

  • 3-catenin
  • Actin and
  • Vimentin.

 

It stains negative for cytokeratin and S-100.

 

  • Treatment includes wide excision with a margin clearance of 2.5cm to avoid recurrence. It is a completely unencapsulated fibroma and is hard to cut. The defect then requires repair using mesh to prevent hernia in the future.
  • Radiotherapy alone is an acceptable treatment option for patients with unresectable desmoid tumors
  • Prognosis is good, with no metastasis or sarcomatous change. Although they lack metastatic potential, they can be multifocal as well as locally aggressive and invasive, with a high propensity for recurrence.

choices.text: Incidence reduces and prevalence remains the same
Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases

questions.text: A team of oncologists is implementing a new treatment strategy for metastatic melanoma that significantly improves overall survival rates for patients. How would you categorize the change in incidence and prevalence of metastatic melanoma in the population treated at this center? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases

 

  • The given scenario shows that there is a new treatment which can extend overall survival but cannot cure a particular disease.
  • So, old cases will live longer and thus, there will be increase in prevalence. Incidence will not get affected due to this.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incidence increases and prevalence reduces: Incorrect as the new treatment does not affect the number of new cases.

 

Option B. Incidence reduces and prevalence remains the same: Incorrect because the incidence is unaffected by treatment, and the prevalence would increase due to longer survival.

 

Option D. Incidence reduces and prevalence increases: Incorrect because the incidence remains the same.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PREVALENCE

 

  • Total current (Old + New) cases in a given population over.
  • Prevalence = Incidence Ã— Mean duration of disease [P = I Ã— d]
  • Prevalence describes the balance between incidence, mortality and recovery

 

INCIDENCE

 

  • Number of new cases occurring in a defined population over a specified period of time.

 

Note - A treatment that extends the lives of patients with a chronic condition will increase prevalence, even if incidence remains stable.

questions.text: Which of the following in IgA vasculitis warrants the use of corticosteroids? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GI bleeding

 

IgA vasculitis, also known as Henoch-SchÃ¶nlein purpura, typically presents with symptoms such as arthritis, abdominal pain, and skin rash. These symptoms are often managed with supportive care and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). However, the use of corticosteroids is reserved for more severe manifestations of the disease.

 

GI bleeding: In cases where IgA vasculitis leads to gastrointestinal bleeding, corticosteroids are warranted. This is because GI bleeding indicates a severe form of the disease involving the gastrointestinal tract, which requires more aggressive treatment to reduce inflammation and prevent further complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arthritis: Joint pain and swelling associated with IgA vasculitis are usually mild and managed with NSAIDs or supportive care. Corticosteroids are not typically indicated for arthritis alone in this context.

 

Option C. Abdominal pain: Abdominal pain in IgA vasculitis can often be managed with supportive care and NSAIDs. Corticosteroids are reserved for severe cases or when there is evidence of significant gastrointestinal involvement.

 

Option D. Skin rash: The characteristic purpuric rash of IgA vasculitis is usually self-limiting and does not require corticosteroids for treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corticosteroids are indicated in IgA vasculitis primarily for severe manifestations such as gastrointestinal bleeding, indicating more extensive disease involvement. Other manifestations, such as arthritis, abdominal pain, and skin rash, are generally self-limiting and respond well to supportive care. Corticosteroids are not typically required for these symptoms unless they are part of a more severe systemic involvement.

questions.text: Researcher was studying the effect of hypoxia, hypercapnia and change in pH on ventilation, when he simulated the condition of hypoxia and hypercapnia with pH of 7.35 and plotted the graph, which one of the following is the appropriate representation of the given condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B

 

 

  • Curve A shows linear relationship between PCO2 and Ventilation i.e hypercapnia (â†‘PCO2) â†’ â†‘ Ventilation
  • Curve B shows effect of hypoxia and hypercapnia on Ventilation i.e when both Hypercapnia and Hypoxia (â†‘PCO2 & â†“O2) are present simultaneously but the pH is normal (unchanged)Ã  slope of the curve also changes hence as a result curve becomes Steeper
  • Curve C shows effect of hypoxia, hypercapnia and acidosis on Ventilation i.e. when hypoxia, hypercapnia and acidosis (â†‘PCO2, â†“O2, â†“pH) are present simultaneously â†’ not only the slope of the curve changes but also the Shift of Apneic Point (point denoting PCO2 Levels Below which apnea i.e stoppage of breathing occurs) is seen.
  • Curve D also shows effect of hypoxia, hypercapnia and acidosis (but in the question pH is Normal 7.35 ) on Ventilation i.e., when hypoxia, hypercapnia and acidosis (â†‘PCO2, â†“O2, â†“pH) are more severe Ã  the slope of the curve will be more steeper with the Shift of Apneic Point.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Curve B represents the condition of simultaneous hypoxia and hypercapnia with normal pH, showing a steeper slope in the relationship between PCO2 and ventilation.

questions.text: When you add calcium and thromboplastin to platelet poor plasma which pathway is assessed? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Extrinsic

 

Thromboplastin (Factor III) binds with Factor VII. When calcium is added, it activates extrinsic pathway.

 

 

Activated Prothrombin Time (aPTT) measures the integrity of the intrinsic system (Factors XII, XI, VIII, IX) and common clotting pathways. Calcium and activating substances (kaolin) are added to the plasma-

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Intrinsic: The intrinsic pathway is assessed using the Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time (aPTT) test, where calcium and an activating substance like kaolin (not thromboplastin) are added to the plasma to measure the activity of Factors XII, XI, IX, and VIII.

 

Option C. Fibrinolysis: Fibrinolysis is the process of breaking down fibrin clots, which is not directly assessed by adding thromboplastin and calcium. It is evaluated by other means, such as measuring fibrin degradation products (FDPs) or D-dimer levels.

 

Option D. Common: While the extrinsic pathway feeds into the common pathway (Factors X, V, II, and I), the specific test described (PT) is primarily assessing the extrinsic pathway, though it also gives some information about the common pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adding calcium and thromboplastin to platelet-poor plasma assesses the extrinsic pathway of coagulation, which is the basis for the Prothrombin Time (PT) test.

questions.text: Which of these labeled structures represents a division of the internal carotid artery? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 4

 

The structure marked 1 and 4 are the anterior ethmoidal artery and posterior ethmoidal artery, which are branches of the ophthalmic division of the internal carotid artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vascular Supply of the Nasal Cavity:

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 198

choices.text: Rocky mountain spotted fever

questions.text: Which disease causes the lesion shown in the image below? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Scrub typhus

 

The lesion shown in the image is eschar. It is seen in scrub typhus.

 

Scrub typhus is an infectious disease caused by the rickettsial bacterium Orientia tsutsugamushi.

 

It is transmitted to humans by the bite of the larva of trombiculid mites. Later it causes disseminated vasculitis and perivascular inflammation ultimately leading to significant vascular leakage leading to end-organ injury.

 

Clinical features usually arise after an incubation period of 6-21 days and manifest as fever, headache, myalgia, and gastrointestinal symptoms. An eschar which usually begins as a primary papular lesion later crusts to form a black ulcer with central necrosis is a distinct feature of scrub typhus although its presence varies in different regions.

 

Other options:

 

Option A: A classic case of Rocky mountain spotted fever (RMSF) involves a rash that appears 2-4 days after the onset of fever as small, flat, pink, macules on the wrists, forearms, and ankles and spreads to include the trunk and sometimes the palms of hands and soles of feet.

 

Option B: Malaria is a protozoal disease caused by Plasmodium species characterized by periodic bouts of fever with chills and rigors, followed by anemia, splenomegaly, and hepatomegaly.

 

Option D: COVID-19 is a highly contagious viral disease caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).

 

Educational Objective

 

Scrub typhus, caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi, is characterized by an eschar at the site of the mite bite, along with fever and systemic symptoms.

questions.text: A 24-year-old P1L1 woman presented with acute abdominal pain. She has a H/O RHD and recently went for mitral valve replacement and is currently on warfarin therapy. On examination, there is a 14-week size abdominal pelvic mass and on USG, a 6 Ã— 8 cm unilocular cyst with reticular appearance is seen. What is the next best step in management of this patient? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Surgical exploration

 

In this case, surgical exploration is the best next step because:

 

  • The patient has a large (6Ã—8 cm) symptomatic ovarian cyst with reticular appearance suggesting hemorrhage
  • The hemorrhagic nature is likely due to warfarin therapy
  • Due to the large size and symptoms (acute abdominal pain), conservative management is not appropriate
  • However, before surgery: 
    • Anticoagulation needs to be stopped
    • INR needs to be corrected (may require vitamin K)
    • Patient may need bridging with heparin
    • Surgery should be performed only after coagulation parameters are normalized

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. MRI:

 

  • Not necessary as USG has already provided clear visualization of the cyst
  • Won't add significant diagnostic value given the clear hemorrhagic appearance on USG

 

Option C. Follow up:

 

  • Not appropriate for a large (6*8 cm) symptomatic cyst
  • Conservative management is suitable for smaller, asymptomatic cysts
  • Risk of continued hemorrhage due to anticoagulation

 

Option D. Measure Ca-125:

 

  • Not indicated as the imaging characteristics suggest a benign hemorrhagic cyst
  • Patient is young and USG findings are not suspicious for malignancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

Large hemorrhagic ovarian cysts in patients on anticoagulation require surgical management after correcting coagulation parameters.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a perineal approach for rectal prolapse? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ripsteinâ€™s procedure

 

The following surgical options are used to treat rectal prolapse:

 

This procedure involves the use of a prosthetic mesh that is placed around the mobilized rectum, with the attachment of the mesh to the presacral fascia (anterior) below the sacral promontory. It is performed using the abdominal approach, which is difficult but has a lower recurrence rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Delorme's operation: This surgical option involves the circumferential stripping of the rectal mucosa over the length of the prolapse. The underlying muscle is plicated with a series of sutures, and the excess rectal mucosa is excised. It is performed using the perineal approach and is associated with less morbidity but has a higher recurrence rate than the abdominal approach.

 

Option C. Thiersch operation: This surgical option involves placing a steel wire or nylon tape around the anal canal to manage partial rectal prolapse. It is largely obsolete now due to problems with chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defecation, and is rarely used.

 

Option D. Altemeier's procedure: This surgical option involves prolapsing the rectum through the anal canal and performing a full-thickness resection, incorporating any associated colonic prolapse. Restoration of colorectal continuity can be performed by hand-sewn/stapled anastomosis. It is the procedure of choice in patients presenting with incarcerated and strangulated prolapse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ripstein's procedure is done for its management using the abdominal approach. The perineal approach is often preferred in elderly patients with high operative risk and limited life expectancy. It involves surgeries such as Delorme's mucosectomy and Thiersch's wiring, which have higher recurrence rates than the abdominal approach.

questions.text: What concentration of tetanus antitoxin in the blood is considered clinically protective against tetanus? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) >0.01 IU/ml

 

  • Specific antibody concentrations greater than 0.01 IU/mL were considered protective against tetanus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aim of active Immunisation with TT:

 

  • Vaccinate the entire community
  • Ensure protective level of antitoxin ~ 0.01 IU/mL serum throughout life

choices.text: Vitamin C

questions.text: Administration of which of the following drugs would increase the bioavailability of saquinavir? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ritonavir


 

  • Both Ritonavir and Saquinavir are Protease inhibitors that can be used in the treatment of HIV.
  • They are metabolized by the hepatic CYP3A4 enzyme system. But at the same time, Ritonavir is also an inhibitor of CYP3A4. Therefore, if small doses of Ritonavir are added along with Saquinavir, it will inhibit the metabolism of Saquinavir or in other words will boost the bioavailability and concentration of Saquinavir.

questions.text: The disruption of which of the following is responsible for watery diarrhea in cholera caused by Vibrio? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Zonula occludens

 

When cholera toxin is released from the bacteria in the infected intestine, it binds to the intestinal cells known as enterocytes through the interaction of the pentameric B subunit of the toxin with the GM1 ganglioside receptor on the intestinal cell, triggering endocytosis of the toxin.

 

Next, the A/B cholera toxin must undergo cleavage of the A1 domain from the A2 domain in order for A1 to become an active enzyme.

 

Once inside the enterocyte, the enzymatic A1 fragment of the toxin A subunit enters the cytosol, where it activates the G protein Gsa through an ADP-ribosylation reaction that acts to lock the G protein in its GTP-bound form, thereby continually stimulating adenylate cyclase to produce cAMP. 

 

The high cAMP levels activate the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR), causing a dramatic efflux of ions and water from infected enterocytes, leading to watery diarrhea.

 

 

The effects of cholera involve the actions of other Vibrio cholerae toxins that aid the pathogen in its colonization, coordinated expression of virulence factors, and toxin action.

 

These additional proteins include

 

  • Zona occludens toxin (zot, involved in Vibrio cholerae invasion by acting to decrease intestinal tissue resistance)
  • Accessory cholera toxin (ace, increases fluid secretion)
  • Toxin-coregulated pilus (tcpA, essential colonisation factor receptor for the CTXf phage)
  • NAG-specific heat-labile toxin (st)
  • Outer membrane porin proteins (ompU and ompT).
  • The expression of virulence factors is controlled by the transcriptional factors ToxR, TcpP and ToxT.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intercalated discs: Found in cardiac muscle cells and involved in cell-to-cell adhesion and electrical coupling, not related to intestinal fluid secretion.

 

Option B. Macula densa: Involved in regulating kidney function and blood pressure, not related to intestinal fluid secretion.

 

Option D. Hemidesmosomes: Involved in cell-to-extracellular matrix adhesion, not related to intestinal fluid secretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The disruption of zonula occludens (tight junctions) by cholera toxin is responsible for the increased permeability of intestinal epithelial cells, leading to the characteristic watery diarrhea seen in cholera.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents to his primary care physician with chest pain and shortness of breath. Further investigation reveals a mediastinal mass on imaging studies. The patient is referred to a specialist for further evaluation. What is the most common type of tumor found in the anterior mediastinum? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thymoma

 

The most common anterior mediastinal tumor is thymoma, while posterior mediastinal tumor is neurogenic tumor.

 

The most common mediastinal tumor in children is neurogenic tumor.

 

  • Thymomas are tumors that originate from the thymus gland located in the mediastinum.
  • They account for a significant portion of mediastinal tumors and are the most common type.
  • Thymomas can vary in terms of malignancy, with some being benign (noncancerous) and others being malignant (cancerous).
  • These tumors can cause chest pain, shortness of breath, and other symptoms when they grow and press on nearby structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Neurogenic: Neurogenic tumors, which originate from nerve tissue, are another type of mediastinal tumor found in posterior mediastinum

 

  • Examples of neurogenic tumors include neuroblastoma and ganglioneuroma.

 

Option C. Lymphoma: Lymphomas can occur in the mediastinum but are less frequent than thymomas.

 

  • Lymphomas originate from lymphatic tissue and can be Hodgkin lymphoma or non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

 

Option D. Bronchial cyst: Bronchial cysts are fluid-filled sacs that can develop in the mediastinum but are relatively rare compared to thymomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, thymoma is the most common type of tumor found in the mediastinum, and it originates from the thymus gland. When a patient presents with chest pain and shortness of breath and is found to have a mediastinal mass on imaging studies, thymoma is a likely consideration among other possible mediastinal tumors

questions.text: How is cerebral perfusion pressure calculated? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mean arterial pressure - intracranial pressure


Cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) is calculated as mean arterial pressure (MAP) - intracranial pressure (ICP).

 

Cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) is the net pressure gradient that drives oxygen delivery to cerebral tissue. It is the difference between the mean arterial pressure (MAP) and the intracranial pressure (ICP), measured in millimeters of mercury (mm Hg). If ICP values are not readily available, central venous pressure (CVP) may be used.

 

Normal CPP lies between 60- and 80-mm Hg,

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) is calculated by subtracting the intracranial pressure (ICP) from the mean arterial pressure (MAP). This measurement is crucial for ensuring adequate blood flow and oxygen delivery to the brain.

questions.text: A 21-year-old male presented in clinic with low back pain & stiffness since 2 months. Modified Schober's test done was positive. An X-ray was done as shown in the image. Most likely diagnosis is:(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • Also known as Marie-Strumpell or Bechterewâ€™s disease.
    • It is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints.
    • HLA B27 is positive in 90% patients.
    • Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis & synovitis.
    • Clinical Presentation:
      • It is most commonly seen in young males aged 15 - 25 years.
      • Most common symptom is dull backache, insidious in onset, associated with morning stiffness and improves with activity.
      • Hip and shoulder joint arthritis may occur. Peripheral joints may also be involved in some.
      • Anterior uveitis is the most common extra-articular manifestation.
  • Diagnostic Criteria: Modified New York Criterion:
    • Essential criteria is definite radiographic sacroiliitis
    • Supporting criteria: one of these three:
      • Inflammatory back pain
      • Limited chest expansion (<5 cm at 4th ICS) {not a reliable criterion in elderly because of pulmonary disorders}
      • Limited lumbar spine motion in both sagittal and frontal plane (Schober test/Modified Schober test).
    • Inflammatory back pain is classified if 4/5 are present
      1. Pain for > 3 months
      2. <40 years age
      3. Insidious onset
      4. Pain improves with exercise
      5. Pain at night
  • Spine radiograph shows:
    • Haziness of sacroiliac (SI) joint margins is the earliest change.
    • Later on, SI joints show irregular subchondral erosions in, sclerotic articular margins, joint space widening and eventually bony ankylosis.
    • Calcification of supraspinous & interspinous ligaments (Dagger sign) and that of sacroiliac and sacrotuberous ligaments.

 

 

Dagger sign

 

  • Enthesopathy: Calcification at the attachment of muscles, tendons & ligaments.
  • Trolley/Tram-track sign: Three linear radiopaque lines due to ligament calcification.
  • Squaring of vertebra, loss of lumbar lordosis and bridging osteophytes (syndesmophytes) are seen.

 

 

Trolley track sign

 

  • Bamboo spine  appearance due to syndesmophytes.

 

 

Bamboo spine

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteoporosis. Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e. there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration. So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phoshatase levels. Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to Dexa scan of 30 year old individual and T score is calculated. WHO classification of values in a DEXA scan are T score 0 to â€“1 is normal, T score â€“1 to â€“2.5 is osteopenia, and T score less than â€“2.5 is osteoporosis. The patient is usually asymptomatic until a vertebral fracture occurs. The x-ray of the spine shows codfish vertebrae.

 

 

Option C. PIVD. Lumbar Disc Herniation is a very common cause of low back pain and unilateral leg pain, known as radiculopathy. The patient usually presents with decreased lumbar movement, paraspinal muscle spasm. The provocative tests like straight leg raise is positive. The x-ray shows decreased space between the affected vertebrae due to disc prolapse.
