Option D. Osteoarthritis. Spine osteoarthritis is the presence of disc degeneration and osteophyte formation. The typical presentation of patients with symptomatic osteoarthritis of the spine is pain, stiffness, and motion restriction, which is commonly accompanied by referred pain. The lumbar spine provides pain located in the buttock and thigh region. Lumbar spine osteoarthritis can be associated with radicular pain above the knee.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image in the question shows the bamboo spine appearance which is characteristic of ankylosing spondylitis.
  • Out of the diagnostic criterias for ankylosing spondylitis, one of the criteria is the positive modified Schoberâ€™s test i.e., limited lumbar spine movement in saggital and frontal planes.

questions.text: Therapeutic index is used for assessing which of the following factors? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Safety

 

Therapeutic Index tells us about the margin of safety for a drug. It is calculated as follows:

 

Therapeutic index = TD50/ED50

 

• TD50 (Median toxic dose) = Dose at which there were toxic effects at 50% of the subjects

• ED50 (Median effect dose) = Dose required to produce a therapeutic effect in 50% of the individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Efficacy: Efficacy refers to the maximum effect a drug can produce, regardless of dose. The therapeutic index does not measure this.

 

Option C. Potency: Potency is the amount of drug needed to produce a given effect. It is not assessed by the therapeutic index.

 

Option D. Toxicity: While toxicity is a component of the therapeutic index (TD50), the index itself is used to measure the safety margin rather than toxicity alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The therapeutic index is used to assess the safety of a drug, indicating the margin between effective and toxic doses. A higher therapeutic index means a drug is safer, with a lower risk of adverse effects at therapeutic doses.

questions.text: A boy presents with fever, night sweats, and neck swelling. The biopsy of swelling showed a starry sky appearance. What is the most likely genetic abnormality seen in this case? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MYC gene

 

The given clinical scenario and the classical histopathological finding of starry sky appearance suggest the diagnosis of Burkitt's lymphoma and the most likely genetic abnormality is the translocation of the MYC gene on chromosome 8. Typical cytogenetic abnormalities is t(8;14) and t(8;22) involving MYC gene on chromosome 8, with overexpression of MYC protein having transforming activity.

 

Burkitt lymphoma is very aggressive (very high Ki67) but responds well to intensive chemotherapy

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RAS: Mutations in the RAS gene are associated with various cancers, including some leukemias and solid tumors, but not specifically with Burkitt's lymphoma.

 

Option C. BCR-ABL: This genetic abnormality is associated with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and some cases of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), not with Burkitt's lymphoma.

 

Option D. p53: Mutations in the p53 gene are common in many types of cancer but are not the defining feature of Burkitt's lymphoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burkitt's lymphoma is characterized by the t(8;14) translocation involving the MYC gene, which leads to the overexpression of the MYC protein, driving the aggressive nature of the disease. The starry sky appearance on histopathology is a key diagnostic feature.

 

Ref: Robbins Pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1123

questions.text: The stain done on a section of liver shown below is: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sweetâ€™s reticulin stain

 

Stain demonstrates reticular fibers of the liver and hence has to be reticulin stain.

 

On microscope - plump hepatocytes are surrounded by rims of atrophic hepatocytes. The variation in parenchymal architecture is not easily seen on an H&E stain, and reticulin staining is required to appreciate the changes in hepatocellular architecture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Warthin starry stain: This stain is typically used to identify organisms such as Helicobacter pylori or spirochetes and is not used for reticulin fibers.

 

Option B. Steiner silver stain: Steiner silver stain is used for the detection of certain microorganisms, like Legionella and Treponema, and is not related to reticulin fibers.

 

Option D. Grimelius silver stain: This stain is used for the detection of neuroendocrine cells by highlighting granules within these cells, and again, it is not related to the reticulin fibers of the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sweetâ€™s reticulin stain is specifically used to demonstrate reticular fibers in the liver, allowing for the visualization of changes in hepatocellular architecture that are not apparent with H&E staining.

choices.text: Making a fist with forearm exercise
Tourniquet should be tied and released as soon as possible
Should be collected in sitting position & better to avoid prolonged immobilization
Sample should be analyzed within 15â€“30 min of collection

questions.text: Which of the following should be prevented when collecting a blood sample for serum calcium? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Making a fist with forearm exercise

 

Making a fist and performing forearm exercises during blood collection for calcium measurement should be prevented, as it can cause muscle ischemia and erroneously increase the calcium value in the sample. This is a practical consideration during blood collection when lab personnel often ask patients to make a fist and perform repetitive movements to better visualize veins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tourniquet should be tied and released as soon as possible: The tourniquet should be tied and released as soon as possible to avoid erroneously high calcium values. In some cases, for repeat calcium or PTH measurements, it's recommended to avoid tourniquet use altogether.

 

Option C. Should be collected in sitting position & better to avoid prolonged immobilization: Collecting samples in sitting position and avoiding prolonged immobilization is recommended, as standing can increase serum calcium levels. Prolonged sitting/immobilization can also affect values due to bone lysis.

 

Option D. Sample should be analyzed within 15â€“30 min of collection: Samples should ideally be analyzed within 15â€“30 minutes of collection. If delay is anticipated, the sample should be kept on ice (good for 2 hours) or centrifuged to obtain plasma/serum (stable at room temperature for 8 hours).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Making a fist and performing forearm exercises during blood collection for calcium measurement should be avoided, as it can falsely elevate calcium levels through muscle ischemia.

questions.text: A woman who is using oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) experiences white vaginal discharge without itching or a foul odor. The discharge causes yellow staining on her underwear. Upon examination, the discharge reveals the presence of typical lactobacilli and an acidic pH. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased normal vaginal discharge

 

The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of Leucorrhea (Increased vaginal discharge). Leucorrhea presents with excessive whitish, yellowish, or greenish vaginal discharge. It is non-irritant, no purulent and non-offensive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vaginal candidiasis: Vaginal candidiasis presents with itching and a white thick, curdy discharge.

 

Option C. Bacterial vaginosis: Bacterial vaginosis is characterized by a thin, gray, foul-smelling discharge.

 

Option D. Chlamydia infection: Chlamydia infection can by asymptomatic or present with discharge but is not associated with yellow discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increased normal vaginal discharge, known as leucorrhea, can occur in women using oral contraceptive pills. This discharge is typically white or yellow, non-irritant, no purulent, no offensive, and associated with the presence of lactobacilli and an acidic pH.

questions.text: A healthcare professional is reviewing vaccine protocols to update patient information materials. In doing so, she focuses on the type of vaccine used for diphtheria prevention. Which option correctly describes the type of diphtheria vaccine? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Toxoid

 

  • The diphtheria vaccine is a toxoid vaccine, which involves the use of toxins produced by the bacterium that causes the disease.
  • These toxins are chemically inactivated to form toxoids, which are safe for use in vaccines but still capable of eliciting a strong immune response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of vaccine -

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of liver failure? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Paracetamol

 

The most common cause of liver failure is paracetamol poisoning.

 

Acetaminophen is the leading cause of drug-induced acute liver failure. The most common prescription drugs causing idiosyncratic injury (that is, drug toxicity unrelated to drug dosage) include antibiotics and, in particular, isoniazid, nonsteroidal analgesics, and anti-seizure.

 

  • Paracetamol poisoning is a medical emergency that requires prompt management to prevent serious liver damage and other complications. The general steps involved in the management of acute paracetamol poisoning:

 

1. Decontamination: If the ingestion of paracetamol occurred within the last 1-2 hours, activated charcoal can be given orally to reduce the absorption of paracetamol.

 

2. Treatment with antidote: N-acetylcysteine (NAC. is the specific antidote for paracetamol poisoning. It is most effective if given within 8 hours of ingestion of the overdose. NAC replenishes the depleted glutathione stores in the liver, which helps to prevent liver damage.

 

3. Monitoring and supportive care: Patients with paracetamol poisoning require close monitoring, particularly for liver and kidney function, electrolytes, blood glucose, and acid-base balance. Treatment with intravenous fluids, glucose and electrolytes may be necessary to maintain fluid and electrolyte balance.

 

RUMACK MATTHEW NOMOGRAM is used for monitoring:

 

 

4. Referral for specialist care: In severe cases of paracetamol poisoning, the patient may require specialist care in a hospital setting, including referral to a liver transplant center.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alcohol: Chronic alcohol consumption is a significant cause of liver disease, including cirrhosis, but paracetamol is the leading cause of acute liver failure.

 

Option C. CCl4 (Carbon Tetrachloride): CCl4 is a chemical that can cause liver damage, but it is not a common cause of liver failure compared to paracetamol.

 

Option D. Pesticides: Certain pesticides can cause liver toxicity, but they are not as common a cause of liver failure as paracetamol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paracetamol poisoning is the most common cause of acute liver failure, the mechanism involves free radical injury and so and it is a medical emergency that requires prompt treatment with N-acetylcysteine (NAC) and close monitoring to prevent serious complications, including liver failure.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease, 11th edition, Pg 1635

questions.text: Brunt sugar smell of urine is due to the defect of? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Branched chain keto acid dehydrogenase

 

Explanation:

 

  • Burnt sugar-like odour is a characteristic feature of Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) which occurs due to the inherited deficiency of branched chain Keto-acid dehydrogenase/decarboxylase.
  • It results in a defect in oxidative phosphorylation and catabolism of branched-chain amino acids (BCAA) Valine/Isoleucine/leucine. As a result, these amino acids are excreted in urine. There is also mental retardation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenylalanine hydroxylase: Deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase leads to phenylketonuria (PKU), which is characterized by a mousy or musty odor due to the accumulation of phenylalanine and its metabolites.

 

Option B. Isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase: Deficiency of isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase causes isovaleric acidemia, which is associated with a rancid, cheesy, or sweaty feet odor due to the accumulation of isovaleric acid.

 

Option C. Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase: Deficiency of fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase leads to tyrosinemia type I, which is characterized by a boiled cabbage or rotten mushrooms odor due to the accumulation of tyrosine and its metabolites.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Arrange the following clotting factors in the order they are activated in the coagulation cascade: 

 

  1. Factor XIII
  2. Factor XII
  3. Factor X
  4. Factor V
  5. Factor XI
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 5, 3, 4, 1

 

The sequence of activation in the coagulation cascade is: Factor XII (2) â†’ Factor XI (5) â†’ Factor X (3) â†’ Factor V (4) â†’ Factor XIII (1). This follows the steps in the intrinsic and common pathways:

 

2. Factor XII (Hageman factor): Triggers the intrinsic pathway by becoming active upon exposure to negatively charged surfaces.

 

5. Factor XI: Is activated by Factor XIIa and continues the intrinsic pathway.

 

3. Factor X: Plays a pivotal role in the common pathway, forming part of the complex that converts prothrombin to thrombin.

 

4. Factor V: Functions as a cofactor in the prothrombinase complex, assisting in the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin.

 

1. Factor XIII: Is activated by thrombin and cross-links fibrin to stabilize the clot.

 

The diagram provided outlines the pathways involved in the coagulation cascade, differentiating between the intrinsic, extrinsic, and common pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of clotting factor activation: XII â†’ XI â†’ X â†’ V â†’ XIII, which follows the intrinsic and common coagulation pathways.

questions.text: Which of these is not an expected complication of Hellerâ€™s operation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gas bloat syndrome

 

  • The most common surgical procedure for achalasia is laparoscopic Heller myotomy, usually performed in conjunction with an anti-reflux procedure (partial fundoplication) to prevent post-operative acid reflux (option B). 
  • During the procedure, the anterior vagus nerve can be injured (option A). Forceful myotomy may also tear the mucosa and lead to perforation (Option D).
  • Gas bloat is seen after fundoplication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Injury to the vagus nerve: It can occur during dissection around the esophagus.

 

Option B. Acid reflux: It can occur especially if the myotomy is not combined with a partial fundoplication, since the LES is weakened.

 

Option D. Esophageal perforation: It can occur due to the delicate nature of the esophageal wall during the procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gas bloat syndrome is more commonly associated with Nissen fundoplication, a procedure for gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
  • It occurs when patients are unable to burp, leading to bloating and discomfort from trapped gas.
  • Thus, gas bloat syndrome is not a complication of Hellerâ€™s myotomy.

questions.text: In triage, immediately life-threatening injury is categorized as what color code? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Red

 

In the triage system, which is used to prioritize patients based on the severity of their condition, an immediately life-threatening injury is classified under the Red color code. This indicates that the patient requires immediate medical attention to prevent death or severe complications. The Red category is the highest priority in triage, where intervention is needed within 0 to 6 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Green: This color code is used for ambulatory patients with non-life-threatening injuries. These patients are stable and can wait for treatment.

 

Option C. Yellow: The Yellow category is for urgent cases where intervention is required within 6 to 24 hours. While these patients need prompt attention, their condition is not as immediately critical as those in the Red category.

 

Option D. Black: The Black category is reserved for patients who are either deceased or moribund (those who are unlikely to survive). This represents the lowest priority in triage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a triage situation, an immediately life-threatening injury is classified under the Red color code, indicating the need for urgent medical intervention.

questions.text:
Arrange the following events in the correct sequence as depicted in the Wiggers diagram:

 

  1. Rapid Ejection
  2. S1 (First Heart Sound)
  3. R wave
  4. T wave
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3, 2, 1, 4

 

The Wiggers diagram illustrates the relationship between electrical and mechanical events during the cardiac cycle. The correct sequence of the given events is:

 

3. R wave: This represents ventricular depolarization on the electrocardiogram (ECG). It initiates ventricular contraction. 

 

2.S1 (First Heart Sound): Following the R wave, ventricular contraction increases intraventricular pressure, leading to the closure of the atrioventricular (mitral and tricuspid) valves. This closure produces the first heart sound, S1. 

 

1.Rapid Ejection: As ventricular pressure surpasses aortic pressure, the aortic valve opens, allowing rapid ejection of blood into the aorta. This phase follows the closure of the atrioventricular valves. 

 

4.T wave: This represents ventricular repolarization on the ECG, occurring after the rapid ejection phase. It signifies the beginning of ventricular relaxation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the cardiac cycle, the sequence of events is: R wave (ventricular depolarization) â†’ S1 (closure of atrioventricular valves) â†’ Rapid Ejection (blood ejection into the aorta) â†’ T wave (ventricular repolarization).

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used in heart failure?(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Trimetazidine

 

Trimetazidine is not used in heart failure because it is primarily a metabolic modulator. It partially inhibits the beta-oxidation of fatty acids, which results in shifting the metabolism of heart muscles from fatty acids to glucose. This shift requires less oxygen, making trimetazidine beneficial for patients with angina pectoris. However, it does not have a role in the management of heart failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metoprolol: Metoprolol is a beta-blocker that is used in the management of chronic heart failure. Beta-blockers are contraindicated in acute heart failure but can be beneficial in chronic heart failure when started at a low dose and gradually increased to avoid decompensation. The beta-blockers commonly used in heart failure include carvedilol, metoprolol, and bisoprolol.

 

Option C. Sacubitril: Sacubitril is an NEP (neutral endopeptidase) inhibitor, which prevents the breakdown of brain natriuretic peptide (BNP). By inhibiting NEP, sacubitril increases BNP levels, leading to natriuresis and vasodilation, which are beneficial effects in chronic heart failure (CHF). Therefore, sacubitril is used in the treatment of CHF.

 

Option D. Nesiritide: Nesiritide is a recombinant form of BNP and is administered through the subcutaneous route. It helps to induce natriuresis and vasodilation, thus can be used in the treatment of heart failure.

 

Educational objective:

 

Trimetazidine, although beneficial for angina pectoris due to its metabolic modulation properties, is not used in the treatment of heart failure.

 

Note - Beta blockers are contraindicated in acute heart failure, but they can be used in chronic heart failure. Beta blockers should be started at low dose, dose should be increased gradually to prevent decompensation.

 

Beta blockers used are – Carvedilol, metoprolol and bisoprolol.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/ 599, 600

choices.text: E1, E2, E5
E6, E7
L1, L2

questions.text: The image below shows the life cycle of a virus. Which of the proteins of the virus act as oncogenes?  (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) E6, E7

 

The image shows the life cycle of the human papilloma virus, and the E6 and E7 proteins act as oncogenes

 

 

  • HPV oncogenes E6 and E7 deregulate host cell cycle by binding and inactivating tumor suppressor genes p53 and pRb.
  • Binding of E6 gene to p53 causes degradation of p53.
  • E7 gene binds to pRb and disrupts the complex between pRb and E2F leading to uncontrolled proliferation. HPV, human papilloma virus.

 

 

 

Educational Objective

 

  • E6 and E7 proteins of HPV are the primary oncogenes responsible for the virus's ability to cause cancer. They do this by inactivating key tumor suppressor proteins, p53 and pRb, leading to uncontrolled cell growth and proliferation.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever for 5 days and retro-orbital pain, suggestive of dengue fever. Which investigation should be conducted next for confirmation? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IgM ELISA

 

For a patient presenting with symptoms suggestive of dengue fever for 5 days, the most appropriate test for confirmation is IgM ELISA. According to national dengue guidelines, NS1 antigen testing is most effective in the first 1-4 days of illness. However, from day 5 onwards, IgM antibodies become detectable, making IgM ELISA the preferred test for confirmation at this stage of the illness.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. NS1 antigen test: While useful for early detection (days 1-4), it's less effective after 5 days of symptoms.

 

Option B. Viral culture: Though it can be used for dengue diagnosis, it's not the preferred method due to time constraints and complexity.

 

Option C. PCR: While sensitive, PCR is most useful in the early stages of infection and may not be the best choice after 5 days of symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For dengue fever confirmation after 5 days of symptoms, IgM ELISA is the most appropriate diagnostic test according to national guidelines.

choices.text: Small doses of regular consumption of alcohol

questions.text: A 48-year-old male presents to the ER with confusion and shaking of the entire body. He has a history of excessive alcohol consumption. What is the cause of delirium tremens in an alcoholic? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute infection

 

Delirium tremens is primarily caused by abrupt alcohol cessation in chronic users.

 

Acute infections can exacerbate or precipitate its onset.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fatty liver: Fatty liver doesn't directly precipitate DT.

 

Option C. Gradual withdrawal of alcohol: Gradual withdrawal typically avoids DT.

 

Option D. Small doses of regular consumption of alcohol: Regular small doses wouldn't lead to abrupt cessation symptoms.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Alcohol withdrawal delirium (DTs) typically presents 48-72 hours after the last drink and is characterized by disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucinations (especially visual), agitation, coarse tremors and autonomic hyperactivity. Risk factors include surgery, infections or other medical conditions. It is a medical emergency requiring prompt intervention. Treatment includes intravenous lorazepam or diazepam with thiamine supplementation to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy.

 

Reference: Shorter Oxford Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 572-573.

choices.text: Collarette scale - Christmas tree pattern - Pityriasis rosea
Christmas tree pattern - Lichen planus

questions.text: A young male, aged 24, has presented with asymptomatic scaly skin lesions on his back, symmetrically distributed. The provided images showcase the lesions. Can you identify the pattern of these skin lesions & the specific disease?(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Collarette scale - Christmas tree pattern - Pityriasis rosea

 

Option A.

 

Collarette scale - Christmas tree pattern - Pityriasis rosea

 

  • Given clinical scenario and images showing Collarette scale (Herald patch) and Christmas tree pattern distributed lesions, points to a diagnosis of Pityriasis rosea.

 

Pityriasis Rosea:

 

  • This is a common skin condition characterized by a herald patch, followed by a distinctive, symmetric rash in a Christmas tree pattern.
  • It primarily affects the back and trunk. The rash is often accompanied by a Collarette scale, where the scale is more prominent at the periphery of the lesion.

 

Christmas Tree Pattern:

 

  • The symmetric distribution and orientation of lesions along the lines of skin cleavage on the back is a hallmark of pityriasis rosea.

 

PITYRIASIS ROSEA

 

  • Acute: Self-limiting (6-12 weeks) disease.
  • Etiology: Most common viral trigger is HHV 7.
  • Asymptomatic >> mild pruritus may be present.
  • Features:
    • 1st lesion: Herald patch / mother patch 1-2 weeks later.
    • Secondary lesions: Scaly papules → oval annular plaques → mild pigmentary changes → fades slowly in 6-12 weeks.
  • Distribution of Lesions: Christmas tree pattern (Downwards & outwards from the spine along the lines of Langer).
  • Treatment: Counsel, self-limiting 6-12 weeks.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Wickham’s Striae - Lichen Planus:

 

  • Wickham's striae are fine, white lines found on the surface of papules in lichen planus.
  • Surface of lichen planus lesions seen with oil on top of lesion reveals these whitish linear streaks.

 

 

  • Lichen planus typically presents with pruritic, purplish, polygonal papules and does not exhibit a Christmas tree pattern.

 

Option C. Christmas Tree Pattern - Lichen Planus:

 

This is incorrect because, although lichen planus is a common dermatologic condition, it does not present with a Christmas tree pattern. This pattern is specific to pityriasis rosea.

 

Option D. Woronoff Ring – Seborrheic Dermatitis:

 

  • The Woronoff ring is a hypopigmented ring surrounding individual psoriatic lesions. It is usually associated with treatment, most commonly UV radiation or topical steroids.

 

 

  • Seborrheic dermatitis presents with greasy, scaly lesions predominantly on the scalp, face, and upper trunk.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When presented with symmetrically distributed, asymptomatic scaly skin lesions on the back in a young adult, consider pityriasis rosea, particularly if the lesions follow a Christmas tree pattern.
  • This pattern, along with the presence of collarette scaling, is highly suggestive of pityriasis rosea.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition page 35.8, 37.3, 115.9

questions.text: A child was being delivered oxygen by nasal canula at 3L/min. What is the FiO2 being delivered?  (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B.  30%

 

Explanation:

 

The fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) delivered by nasal cannula increases by approximately 4% for every 1 liter per minute of oxygen flow. Thus:

 

  • 1 L/min would raise the FiO2 to about 24%.
  • 2 L/min would be about 28%.
  • 3 L/min would be about 32%.

 

Given the options provided, the closest and most commonly accepted approximation for the FiO2 being delivered at a flow rate of 3 L/min through a nasal cannula would be around 30%.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 25%: This FiO2 would typically correspond to an oxygen flow rate of about 1 L/min via nasal cannula.

 

Option C. 40%: This FiO2 would typically correspond to an oxygen flow rate of about 5 L/min via nasal cannula.

 

Option D. 45%: This FiO2 would typically correspond to an oxygen flow rate of about 6 L/min via nasal cannula.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The FiO2 delivered by a nasal cannula at a flow rate of 3 L/min is approximately 30%.

1, 2 and 4

questions.text:
The anti-epileptic drugs which can also be used for the treatment of neuropathic pain are: (INICET Nov 2021)

 

1. Pregabalin

2. Carbamazepine

3. Lamotrigine

4. Gabapentin
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1, 2 and 4

 

The question relates to the use of certain anti-epileptic drugs (AEDs) for the treatment of neuropathic pain.

 

  1. Pregabalin: This is an AED that's also commonly used for neuropathic pain. It works by binding to calcium channels in the central nervous system and reducing the release of neurotransmitters. It is used in the management of neuropathic pain associated with diabetic peripheral neuropathy, spinal cord injury or postherpetic neuralgia.

 

  1. Carbamazepine: Initially used as an anti-seizure medication, carbamazepine is also effective for certain types of neuropathic pain, particularly trigeminal neuralgia.

 

4. Gabapentin: Similar to pregabalin, gabapentin is used both as an AED and for the treatment of neuropathic pain. It also affects calcium channels and reduces neurotransmitter release. It is mainly used in the management of neuropathic pain due to postherpetic neuralgia in adults.

 

Other Options:

 

  1. Lamotrigine: While lamotrigine is an AED, its use in neuropathic pain is less established compared to pregabalin and carbamazepine. It may have some efficacy, but it's not a first-line treatment for neuropathic pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pregabalin, carbamazepine, and gabapentin are anti-epileptic drugs that are also effective in treating neuropathic pain. These medications are utilized not only for seizure control but also for managing various forms of chronic pain associated with nerve damage.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of central cyanosis? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypothermia

 

Central cyanosis occurs when there is a significant amount of deoxygenated hemoglobin in the blood, typically due to issues with oxygenation or hemoglobin abnormalities.

 

In contrast, hypothermia leads to peripheral cyanosis, not central cyanosis. In hypothermia, the blood flow is sluggish due to vasoconstriction, particularly in the extremities, which results in a bluish discoloration of the skin. However, the central organs typically remain oxygenated.

 

Other Options:

 

Central cyanosis can be caused by several factors:

 

Option A. Methemoglobinemia: This condition involves the presence of methemoglobin in the blood, which does not carry oxygen effectively, leading to central cyanosis.

 

Option B. Pulmonary Arteriovenous Fistula: This abnormal connection between an artery and a vein in the lungs allows blood to bypass the alveoli, leading to poorly oxygenated blood entering the systemic circulation, causing central cyanosis.

 

Option C. High Altitude: At high altitudes, the reduced atmospheric pressure leads to lower oxygen availability, causing hypoxemia and central cyanosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypothermia causes only peripheral cyanosis due to sluggish blood flow, not central cyanosis

questions.text: A 4-year-old child with weight for height less than minus 1 SD & height for age is minus 2 SD. What is the best possible assessment?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic malnutrition

 

Chronic malnutrition, also known as stunting, is indicated by a height for age that is significantly below the normal. According to World Health Organization (WHO) standards, a height for age that is less than minus 2 standard deviations (SD) from the median of the reference population is indicative of stunting. In this question, the child has a height for age of minus 2 SD, which points to chronic malnutrition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute malnutrition: This is typically indicated by a significant weight loss over a short period, reflected in weight for height measurements. A weight for height less than minus 3 SD from the median would indicate severe acute malnutrition, but in this case, the weight for height is less than minus 1 SD, which is not sufficient to diagnose acute malnutrition.

 

Option C. Acute on chronic malnutrition: This would be indicated if the child had signs of both chronic malnutrition (height for age less than minus 2 SD) and significant recent weight loss. However, the weight for height is only less than minus 1 SD, not indicative of acute malnutrition.

 

Option D. None of the above: This is incorrect as chronic malnutrition is clearly indicated by the height for age of minus 2 SD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic malnutrition is diagnosed when a child's height for age is less than minus 2 standard deviations from the median of the reference population, indicating stunting.

choices.text: Sense changes in muscle direction
Sense changes in muscle tension
Sense changes in position of the muscle
Sense changes in length of the muscle

questions.text: The function of the Golgi tendon organ is to? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sense changes in muscle tension

 

The Golgi tendon organ functions as a crucial sensory receptor that provides important feedback to the central nervous system, contributing to muscle control, injury prevention, and maintaining appropriate muscle tension during various activities.

 

The Golgi tendon organ is an encapsulated sensory receptor through which muscle tendon fibers pass. About 10 to 15 muscle fibers are usually connected to each Golgi tendon organ, and the organ is stimulated when this small bundle of muscle fibers is “tensed” by contracting or stretching the muscle.

 

The major difference in excitation of the Golgi tendon organ versus the muscle spindle is that the spindle detects muscle length and changes in muscle length, whereas the tendon organ detects muscle tension as reflected by the tension in itself.

 

Golgi tendon reflex (Inverse myotatic/ Inverse stretch reflex)

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Sense changes in muscle direction: Incorrect. Muscle direction changes are not detected by the Golgi tendon organ but by proprioceptors in the muscle and joints.

 

Option C. Sense changes in position of the muscle: Incorrect. This function is primarily performed by muscle spindles and joint receptors, not by the Golgi tendon organ.

 

Option D. Sense changes in length of the muscle: Incorrect. Muscle spindles are responsible for detecting changes in muscle length and the rate of change in length, not the Golgi tendon organ.

 

Educational Objective

 

The Golgi tendon organ is responsible for sensing changes in muscle tension, providing crucial feedback to the central nervous system to prevent muscle damage and maintain appropriate muscle tension during various activities.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most effective oral drug in smoking cessation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Varenicline


Varenicline is the most effective oral drug for smoking cessation.

 

Nicotine is the principal constituent of tobacco responsible for its addictive behavior. Varenicline works by blocking the effects of nicotine on the brain. It blocks α4 and β2 nicotinic acetylcholine receptor subtypes and inhibits dopaminergic activation produced by smoking through their partial agonism. This mechanism decreases the craving and withdrawal syndrome that occurs with cessation attempts. It prevents nicotine stimulation of the mesolimbic dopamine system associated with nicotine addiction, thus helping to occlude the rewarding effect of smoking.

 

Varenicline is prescribed only to patients 18 years or older. It is taken orally, and the dose is 0.5 mg once daily on days 1 to 3, increased to 0.5 mg twice daily on days 4 through 7, and 1 mg twice daily after day 8 for 11 weeks. Therapy should start one week before the target quit date. It can be continued for another 12 weeks (1 mg BD) to maintain abstinence.

 

The adverse effects include nausea, disturbed sleep, sleepwalking, agitation, drowsiness, and constipation, and it may also increase the risk of pancreatitis. Varenicline has been implicated in specific skin syndromes such as Stevens-Johnson syndrome, erythema multiforme, and photosensitivity. Varenicline can cause renal failure and kidney stones, so renal function must be monitored.

 

The FDA has issued a warning about mood and behavioral changes associated with its use, and there is some evidence of increased cardiovascular risk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cevimeline: Cevimeline is a muscarinic agonist with an affinity for both M1 and M3 receptors on the lacrimal and salivary glands. While M1 activation results in increased secretion, M3 activation results in smooth muscle contraction and expulsion of the secretions. Cevimeline enhances lacrimal secretions in Sjogren’s syndrome.

 

Option C. Muscarine: Muscarine is a natural alkaloid that acts on muscarinic acetylcholine receptors but is not involved in smoking cessation.

 

Option D. Atropine: Atropine is an antimuscarinic agent that blocks the action of acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors and is not used for smoking cessation.

 

Educational Objective:


Varenicline is a partial agonist of the α4 and β2 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors and is the most effective oral drug for smoking cessation. It blocks dopaminergic stimulation and reduces the rewarding effects of nicotine.

questions.text: Identify the type of drain: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Closed

 

The image displays a Romovac drain placed after mastectomy, which is a closed-type drain. Drains are utilized at surgical sites to collect air or fluid buildup, promoting wound healing by preventing cavity formation. Drains can be prophylactic in elective surgeries and therapeutic in emergency surgeries, with open, semi-open, and closed types.

 

They carry out their actions through suction

 

  • Eg. Romovac drain, Jackson Pratt drain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open: They are based on the principle of gravity or capillary effect

 

  • Eg. Corrugated drain, Foleyâ€™s catheter etc.\

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Romovac drain is a closed negative suction drain placed in subcutaneous tissue and indicated in modified radical mastectomy, subcutaneous swelling excision, and amputations. Other specialized drains include chest drains for air removal from the pleural cavity and T-tubes for bile drainage after surgical exploration of the bile duct.

questions.text: Locally advanced breast cancer can be defined as all except? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tumor more than 4 cm

 

While a tumor size larger than 4 cm is indicative of a relatively large tumor, it alone does not define locally advanced breast cancer. Locally advanced breast cancer typically involves not only tumor size but also the extent of its spread to nearby structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inflammatory breast cancer: Inflammatory breast cancer is an aggressive subtype of breast cancer characterized by redness, swelling, and warmth in the breast. It is considered an advanced stage of breast cancer.

 

Option C. Chest wall involvement: Locally advanced breast cancer is often defined by its involvement of the chest wall. This means that the cancer has spread beyond the breast tissue and may affect the underlying muscles and structures of the chest wall.

 

Option D. Skin involvement: Skin involvement, such as changes in the appearance of the skin over the breast like peauâ€™d orange or ulceration, can be a feature of locally advanced breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tumor more than 5 cm, not 4 is classified as LABC.

 

Locally advanced breast cancer (LABC) includes: (Mnemonic â€“ CUBE N2)

 

C - Chest wall invasion

 

U - Ulceration of skin

 

B - Both (chest wall invasion and ulceration of skin)

 

E - E(I)nflammatory carcinoma

 

N2 - fixed axillary lymph nodes

choices.text: Fasciculation at the level of lesion
Upper motor neuron lesion and lower motor neuron lesion

questions.text: Which of the following does not help in the localization of lesions in the spinal cord? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Contralateral hemiplegia

 

When localizing lesions in the spinal cord, it is crucial to understand how different tracts and their associated functions are affected:

 

  1. Corticospinal Tract: Damage to this tract results in ipsilateral hemiparesis (weakness) below the level of the lesion. This is because the corticospinal tract crosses over (decussates) at the medulla, above the spinal cord. Therefore, damage at the spinal cord level affects the same side of the body.
  2. Posterior Column: Damage here leads to ipsilateral loss of light touch, vibration, proprioception, and pressure. Similar to the corticospinal tract, the posterior column pathways decussate above the spinal cord.
  3. Spinothalamic Tract: This tract, responsible for pain and temperature sensation, crosses at the level of the spinal cord itself. Damage to the spinothalamic tract results in contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation.

 

Given these pathways, contralateral hemiplegia suggests a lesion above the spinal cord, typically above the pyramidal decussation in the brainstem or higher. Therefore, it does not help in localizing lesions within the spinal cord itself.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fasciculation at the level of lesion: Fasciculations are a sign of lower motor neuron involvement, which can occur at the level of the spinal cord lesion due to damage to the anterior horn cells. This helps in localizing the lesion.

 

Option C. Upper motor neuron lesion and lower motor neuron lesion: The presence of both upper motor neuron (UMN) and lower motor neuron (LMN) signs can be indicative of a spinal cord lesion. UMN signs (such as spasticity and hyperreflexia) occur below the lesion, while LMN signs (such as fasciculations and muscle atrophy) occur at the level of the lesion.

 

Option D. Bladder involvement: Bladder and bowel dysfunction are common in transverse spinal cord lesions. This is due to the involvement of the autonomic pathways that control these functions, helping to localize the lesion within the spinal cord.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Contralateral hemiplegia indicates a lesion above the spinal cord, specifically above the level of pyramidal decussation.

questions.text: Although CECT thorax is required for the diagnosis of all lung carcinomas, MRI is specifically useful in which of the following cases.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pancoast tumor 

 

MRI is particularly beneficial in assessing Pancoast tumors because these tumors are located at the lung apex and commonly extend into surrounding soft tissues, such as the brachial plexus and chest wall. MRI provides superior visualization of soft tissue structures compared to CECT, making it essential for evaluating the extent of the tumor, especially in cases of nerve root involvement, and for pre-surgical planning.

 

Pancoast syndrome, also known as superior sulcus tumor syndrome, results from a tumor at the lung apex infiltrating the C8, T1, and T2 nerve roots. This often leads to severe pain radiating along the ulnar nerve distribution of the arm and may be accompanied by destruction of the first and second ribs.

 

Clinical features of Pancoast tumors include:

 

  • Pain: Typically radiates along the ulnar nerve pathway in the arm.
  • Respiratory symptoms: May include cough, hemoptysis (coughing up blood), wheezing, stridor, and post-obstructive pneumonitis due to central or endobronchial tumor growth.

 

Possible complications from regional tumor spread:

 

  • Tracheal obstruction: Leading to breathing difficulties.
  • Esophageal compression: Resulting in dysphagia (difficulty swallowing).
  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis: Causing hoarseness.
  • Phrenic nerve involvement: Causing an elevated hemidiaphragm and shortness of breath.
  • Hornerâ€™s syndrome: A condition caused by sympathetic nerve damage, characterized by enophthalmos (sunken eyes), ptosis (drooping eyelid), miosis (pupil constriction), and anhydrosis (lack of sweating) on the affected side.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Small cell lung carcinoma: Incorrect: Small cell lung carcinoma is primarily evaluated with CECT, which is sufficient for staging and diagnosis. MRI is typically used only when there is suspected metastasis to the brain or spinal cord.

 

Option B. Adenocarcinoma: Incorrect: Adenocarcinoma does not usually require MRI for routine evaluation. CECT remains the standard imaging modality for determining tumor characteristics and metastatic spread.

 

Option C. Carcinoid: Incorrect: Carcinoid tumors are well assessed with CECT. MRI is not commonly indicated unless soft tissue involvement needs further assessment or the tumor has atypical features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MRI is crucial for Pancoast tumors due to its ability to provide detailed imaging of soft tissue and nerve involvement, which is essential for accurate staging and surgical planning.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old child presents with altered sensorium, persistent headache, and photophobia for the past 5 days. On examination, he has signs of meningeal irritation. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis reveals:what is your diagnosis?
Protein: 93 mg/dL


Glucose: 20 mg/dL (serum glucose = 90 mg/dL)


Cell count: Predominantly lymphocytic pleocytosis (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tubercular meningitis

 

  • Tubercular meningitis is often associated with CSF findings of elevated protein, decreased glucose, and lymphocytic pleocytosis. These findings are consistent with the given CSF results.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial meningitis: The CSF findings of elevated protein, decreased glucose, and an increased number of neutrophil predominance (not lymphocytes) are suggestive of meningitis. However, bacterial meningitis is more commonly associated with a significantly higher white blood cell count (pleocytosis) in the CSF. The given CSF results are not typical for bacterial meningitis.

 

Option B. Viral meningitis: This is a potential consideration. Viral meningitis can present with elevated protein, normal or mildly reduced glucose, and an increased number of lymphocytes in the CSF. It is a common cause of aseptic (non-bacterial) meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Coxsackie viral meningitis and Hand Foot Mouth disease

questions.text: A child presents with fever and vesicular lesions on the upper limb and the lower limb. Neck stiffness was present. Similar lesions were present on the palms, soles, and oral cavity. CSF analysis revealed normal glucose levels and elevated lymphocytes and protein. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coxsackie viral meningitis and Hand Foot Mouth disease

 

The clinical vignette and images provided suggest HFMD meningitis.

 

The presence of vesicular lesions on the palms, soles, and oral cavity, as well as images of the lesions, suggest Hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD). The presence of neck stiffness, as well as CSF with normal glucose levels, elevated lymphocytes, and protein levels, suggests viral meningitis.

 

Therefore the best answer is - Coxsackie viral meningitis and Hand Foot Mouth disease

 

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease:

 

Causes:

 

  • Hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD) is commonly caused by coxsackievirus A16 which is a subgroup of enteroviruses.
  • In large outbreaks, other enteroviruses like enterovirus71, coxsackie A viruses 5,6,7,9, 10 and coxsackie B virus 2 and 5 may also cause HFMD.

 

Clinical features: HFMD is often a minor condition.

 

  • The tongue, posterior pharynx, buccal mucosa, palate, lips, etc. may all have vesicular lesions.
  • Lesions that are maculopapular, vesicular, or pustular may appear on the hands, fingers, buttocks, or groin.
  • Compared to the feet, lesions are more frequently found on the hands.
  • These vesicles disappear within a week.
  • Enterovirus 71 infections are more serious and are linked to cardiovascular and neurological symptoms.
  • Complications from coxsackievirus A16 infections might occasionally include shock, encephalitis, acute flaccid paralysis, and myocarditis.
  • A severe variant of HFMD called atypical HFMD is caused by coxsackievirus A6.

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • HFMD is usually diagnosed clinically by the characteristic lesions.
  • Viral culture can be done to confirm the presence of enterovirus. Blood, CSF, urine, and mucosal swabs can be cultured.
  • RT-PCR testing to detect the viral genome is more sensitive and specific.
  • PCR testing of CSF in children with meningitis is frequently positive even when the cultures are negative.

 

Treatment:

 

  • No specific antiviral agent is proven to be effective against enteroviruses. Supportive care is the mainstay of treatment.
  • Milrinone is suggested as an effective agent for enterovirus 71 cardiopulmonary disease.
  • Immunoglobulins have been used to manage severe cases but with varying outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial meningitis with sepsis: Bacterial meningitis with sepsis is not a likely differential diagnosis for vesicular lesions with this distribution. HSV encephalitis manifests with typical findings of injury to the frontal or parietal cortex or limbic system, including anosmia, memory loss, focal seizures, expressive aphasia, and peculiar behaviour.

 

Option C. Herpes simplex gingivostomatitis and meningoencephalitis: Despite having vesicular lesions, meningoencephalitis and herpes simplex gingivostomatitis show differently clinically. High-grade fever, rapid onset of excruciating mouth pain, and saliva dribbling are the symptoms of HSV gingivostomatitis.

 

Option D. Tuberculous meningitis: Tuberculous meningitis is improbable given the absence of a history of exposure to TB. CSF results in bacterial meningitis often include reduced glucose and raised neutrophils and protein levels. In most cases, CSF results in tuberculous meningitis demonstrate decreased glucose and high amount

 

The majority of the time, CSF results in tuberculous meningitis demonstrate decreased glucose levels, increased lymphocytes, and protein levels.

 

  • Other possible differentials for vesicular lesions include hand-foot-and-mouth disease, varicella (chickenpox), and herpangina.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coxsackie viral infection can cause Hand-foot-and-mouth disease with associated viral meningitis, characterized by vesicular lesions on the palms, soles, and oral cavity, along with normal glucose and elevated lymphocytes in CSF.

questions.text: A clinician is examining various approaches to determine the rate at which a contraceptive method fails. Which index is specifically employed for this purpose? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Pearl index

 

  • Pearl index is the common method used to measure contraceptive failure rate.
  • It is defined as the number of failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY). This rate is given by the formula:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pharmacological index: This term is generally refers to the study and categorization of drugs based on their effects and properties.

 

Option C. Performance index: This may refer to various metrics used to evaluate the performance of processes or systems in different fields.

 

Option D. Efficacy index: While this might be used to measure the effectiveness of a treatment or intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Pearl Index is the standard measure used to determine the contraceptive failure rate, defined as the number of failures per 100 woman-years of exposure.
  • This index helps in evaluating the reliability and effectiveness of various contraceptive methods

questions.text: The following slide is given as a spotter in your microbiology practical examination. Identify the following organism? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mycobacteria

 

  • The image shows pink non-branching acid-fast bacilli on a blue background. These findings are consistent with the staining characteristics of mycobacteria. The stain used is the Ziehl-Neelsen stain.
  • Nocardia is partially acid-fast and appears as branching filaments.
  • Actinomyces and Corynebacterium are non-acid-fast.

 

Other Options:

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis, appear as pink bacilli on a blue background when stained with Ziehl-Neelsen stain due to their acid-fast properties.
  • They have a high lipid content in their cell walls, which retains the carbol fuchsin dye even after treatment with acid-alcohol, a hallmark of acid-fast organisms.

questions.text: In what sequence do muscles develop rigor mortis, progressing from early to late? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Orbicularis oculi, facial muscles, thorax, upper limb

 

Nysten's rule describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis in various muscle groups.

 

Rigor mortis begins from the head and progresses down the body. The order of appearance of rigor mortis is:

 

  1. Myocardium
  2. Eyelids
  3. Neck and lower jaw
  4. Face
  5. Chest
  6. Upper extremities
  7. Abdomen
  8. Legs
  9. Fingers and toes

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rigor mortis

 

Rigor mortis is the post-mortem stiffening and contraction of muscles in the body, resulting from the depletion of energy stores, usually becoming noticeable a few hours after death and gradually resolving over time.â€
